myelopathy: any disease or disorder of the spinal cord or bone marrow
lumbar: of, relating to, or constituting the loins or the vertebrae between the thoracic vertebrae and sacrum
neutrophilic: staining to the same degree with acid or basic dyes
near: the point nearest the eye at which an object is accurately focused on the retina when the maximum degree of accommodation is employed
gases: a fluid (as air) that has neither independent shape nor volume but tends to expand indefinitely
cardiolipin: a phospholipid obtained especially from beef heart and used in combination with lecithin and cholesterol as an antigen in diagnostic blood tests for syphilis
catarrh: inflammation of a mucous membrane in humans or animals; especially : one chronically affecting the human nose and air passages
visceral: of, relating to, or located on or among the viscera
leishmaniasis: a parasitic disease chiefly of tropical and subtropical regions that occurs in cutaneous and systemic forms and is caused by a flagellate protozoan of the genus Leishmania which is transmitted by sand flies (genus Phlebotomus and Lutzomyia) and infects the macrophages of mammalian hosts
gastroschisis: congenital fissure of the ventral abdominal wall
steatorrhoea: an excess of fat in the stools
rhinitis: inflammation of the mucous membrane of the nose marked especially by rhinorrhea, nasal congestion and itching, and sneezing; also : any of various conditions characterized by rhinitis
viii: a glycoprotein clotting factor of blood plasma that is essential for blood clotting and is absent or inactive in hemophilia called also antihemophilic factor, thromboplastinogen
tic: local and habitual spasmodic motion of particular muscles especially of the face : twitching
von: a glycogen storage disease that is caused by a deficiency of glucose-6-phosphate and has a clinical onset at birth or during infancy, that is characterized especially by enlargement of the liver and kidney, hypoglycemia, hyperlipidemia, hyperuricemia, acidosis, adiposity, xanthomas, and nosebleeds, and is inherited as an autosomal recessive trait
haemophilia: a tendency to uncontrollable bleeding; especially : a hereditary, sex-linked blood disorder occurring almost exclusively in males that is marked by delayed clotting of the blood with prolonged or excessive internal or external bleeding after injury or surgery and in severe cases spontaneous bleeding into joints and muscles and that is caused by a deficiency of clotting factors
aggregation: formed by the collection of units or particles into a body, mass, or amount
hemianaesthesia: loss of sensation in either lateral half of the body
irregularity: the quality or state of being irregular
subacute: falling between acute and chronic in character especially when closer to acute
hypotonia: abnormally low pressure of the intraocular fluid
rosacea: a chronic inflammatory skin disorder typically involving the nose, cheeks, forehead, and chin that is characterized especially by redness, flushing, telangiectasia, inflamed lesions, burning sensation, and sometimes eye dryness and irritation and thickening of tissues especially of the nose —called also acne rosacea
appendicitis: inflammation of the vermiform appendix called also epityphlitis
milk: a fluid secreted by the mammary glands of females for the nourishment of their young
breech: the hind end of the body : buttocks
presentation: the position in which the fetus lies in the uterus in labor with respect to the opening of the uterus
hyperprolactinaemia: the presence of an abnormally high concentration of prolactin in the blood
triglycerides: any of a group of lipids that are esters formed from one molecule of glycerol and three molecules of one or more fatty acids, are widespread in adipose tissue, and commonly circulate in the blood in the form of lipoproteins called also neutral fat
mydriasis: excessive or prolonged dilation of the pupil of the eye
secondary: not first in order of occurrence or development: as
nosocomial: acquired or occurring in a hospital
testosterone: a male hormone that is a crystalline hydroxy steroid ketone C19H28O2 produced primarily by the testes or made synthetically and that is the main androgen responsible for inducing and maintaining male secondary sex characteristics
wave: a disturbance or variation that transfers energy progressively from point to point in a medium and that may take the form of an elastic deformation or of a variation of pressure, electrical or magnetic intensity, electrical potential, or temperature
inversion: a reversal of position, order, form, or relationship: as
burn: to produce or undergo discomfort or pain
cavity: an unfilled space within a mass
thirst: a sensation of dryness in the mouth and throat associated with a desire for liquids; also : the bodily condition (as of dehydration) that induces this sensation
dyschezia: constipation associated with a defective reflex for defecation
enterocolitis: enteritis affecting both the large and small intestine
cardiovascular: of, relating to, or involving the heart and blood vessels
nipple: the protuberance of a mammary gland upon which in the female the lactiferous ducts open and from which milk is drawn
erythropsia: a visual disturbance in which all objects appear reddish
glomerulonephritis: acute or chronic nephritis that involves inflammation of the capillaries of the renal glomeruli, has various causes (such as streptococcal infection, lupus, or vasculitis) or may be of unknown cause, is marked especially by blood or protein in the urine and by edema, and if untreated may lead to kidney failure
basement: a thin extracellular supporting layer that separates a layer of epithelial cells from the underlying lamina propria and is composed of the basal lamina and reticular lamina
membrane: a thin soft pliable sheet or layer especially of animal or plant origin
haemangioma: a usually benign tumor made up of blood vessels that typically occurs as a purplish or reddish slightly elevated area of skin
supply: to furnish (organs, tissues, or cells) with a vital element (as blood or nerve fibers) used of nerves and blood vessels
tuberous: characterized by or being knobby or nodular lesions
hypergastrinaemia: the presence of an excess of gastrin in the blood
diverticulum: an abnormal pouch or sac opening from a hollow organ (as the colon or bladder)
mononucleosis: an abnormal increase of mononuclear white blood cells in the blood; specifically : infectious mononucleosis
anion: the ion in an electrolyzed solution that migrates to the anode; broadly : a negatively charged ion
gap: a break in continuity especially of structure : hiatus
hypophosphataemia: deficiency of phosphates in the blood that is due to inadequate intake, excessive excretion, or defective absorption and that results in various abnormalities (as defects of bone)
analysis: separation of a whole into its component parts
hypersexuality: exhibiting unusual or excessive concern with or indulgence in sexual activity
chorioretinitis: inflammation of the retina and choroid of the eye
cryptorchism: a condition in which one or both testes fail to descend normally
b-cell: any of the lymphocytes that have antigen-binding antibody molecules on the surface, that comprise the antibody-secreting plasma cells when mature, and that in mammals differentiate in the bone marrow called also B lymphocyte
iatrogenic: induced unintentionally by a physician or surgeon or by medical treatment or diagnostic procedures
orthognathic: correcting deformities of the jaw and the associated malocclusion
incoherent: lacking clarity or intelligibility usually by reason of some emotional stress
chikungunya: a febrile disease that resembles dengue, occurs especially in parts of Africa, India, and southeastern Asia, and is caused by a togavirus of the genus Alphavirus (species Chikungunya virus) transmitted by mosquitoes especially of the genus Aedes called also chikungunya fever
aspiration: a drawing of something in, out, up, or through by or as if by suction: as
long: an IgG antibody that often occurs in the plasma of patients with Graves' disease —abbreviation LATS
hypogonadism: functional incompetence of the gonads especially in the male with subnormal or impaired production of hormones and germ cells
grief: deep and poignant emotional distress caused by or as if by bereavement; also : a cause of such suffering
enteropathy: a disease of the intestinal tract
pasteurella: a genus of gram-negative facultatively anaerobic nonmotile rod bacteria of the family Pasteurellaceae that stain differentially at the poles of the cell and include several important pathogens especially of domestic animals
abuser: to use excessively; also : to use without medical justification
coital: physical union of male and female genitalia accompanied by rhythmic movements : sexual intercourse
creutzfeldt-jakob: a rare progressive fatal prion disease marked by the development of porous brain tissue, premature dementia in middle age, and gradual loss of muscular coordination abbreviation CJDcalled also Jakob-Creutzfeldt disease
bilateral: of, relating to, or affecting the right and left sides of the body or the right and left members of paired organs
cleaning: to brush (the teeth) with a cleanser (as a dentifrice)
alcoholism: continued excessive or compulsive use of alcoholic drinks
colorectal: relating to or affecting the colon and the rectum
peptide: any of various amides that are derived from two or more amino acids by combination of the amino group of one acid with the carboxyl group of another and are usually obtained by partial hydrolysis of proteins
cell-mediated: relating to or being the part of immunity or the immune response that is mediated primarily by T cells and especially cytotoxic T cells rather than by antibodies secreted by B cells
load: a mass or weight put on something
angiopathy: a disease of the blood or lymph vessels
fulminans: purpura of an often severe progressive form especially of children that is characterized by widespread necrosis of the skin and that occurs chiefly in conjunction with acute infection (as by meningococci) especially as a manifestation of disseminated intravascular coagulation and that in neonates is typically associated with deficiency of protein C or protein S
pulse: a regularly recurrent wave of distension in arteries that results from the progress through an artery of blood injected into the arterial system at each contraction of the ventricles of the heart
torsade: ventricular tachycardia that is characterized by fluctuation of the QRS complexes around the electrocardiographic baseline, is typically caused by a long QT interval, and may lead to life-threatening ventricular fibrillation
pointes: ventricular tachycardia that is characterized by fluctuation of the QRS complexes around the electrocardiographic baseline, is typically caused by a long QT interval, and may lead to life-threatening ventricular fibrillation
vaccine: a preparation that is administered (as by injection) to stimulate the body's immune response against a specific infectious agent or disease: such as
suffocation: the act of suffocating or state of being suffocated : stoppage of breathing
iga: a class of immunoglobulins that include antibodies found in external bodily secretions (as saliva, tears, and sweat)
bile: a yellow or greenish alkaline fluid that is secreted by the liver, stored and concentrated in the gallbladder, and passed into the duodenum where it aids especially in the emulsification and absorption of fats
duct: a bodily tube or vessel especially when carrying the secretion of a gland
morphology: a branch of biology that deals with the form and structure of animals and plants especially with respect to the forms, relations, metamorphoses, and phylogenetic development of organs apart from their functions
rest: a state of repose or sleep
breakthrough: infection occurring in someone who is fully vaccinated against an infectious agent often used before another noun
nocardiosis: actinomycosis caused by actinomycetes of the genus Nocardia and characterized by production of spreading granulomatous lesions
postural: of, relating to, or involving posture; also : orthostatic
phobia: an exaggerated and often disabling fear usually inexplicable to the subject and having sometimes a logical but usually an illogical or symbolic object, class of objects, or situation
anorexia: loss of appetite especially when prolonged
agoraphobia: abnormal fear of being helpless in a situation from which escape may be difficult or embarrassing that is characterized initially often by panic or anticipatory anxiety and finally by avoidance of open or public places
paranoia: a psychosis characterized by systematized delusions of persecution or grandeur usually without hallucinations
embolus: an abnormal particle (as an air bubble) circulating in the blood
high: having a complex organization : greatly differentiated or developed phylogenetically usually used in the comparative degree of advanced types of plants and animals
density: the quantity per unit volume, unit area, or unit length: as
lipoprotein: any of a large class of conjugated proteins composed of a complex of protein and lipid
insufficiency: the quality or state of not being sufficient: as
apgar: an index used to evaluate the condition of a newborn infant based on a rating of 0, 1, or 2 for each of the five characteristics of color, heart rate, response to stimulation of the sole of the foot, muscle tone, and respiration with 10 being a perfect score
mycotic: of, relating to, or characterized by mycosis
reticulocytopenia: an abnormal decrease in the number of reticulocytes in the blood
sickle: a dental scaler with a curved 3-sided point
substance: physical material from which something is made or which has discrete existence
false: not corresponding to truth or reality
cardiogenic: originating in the heart or caused by a cardiac condition
scrotal: of or relating to the scrotum
aspergillus: a genus of ascomycetous fungi with branched radiate sporophores including many common molds
atrioventricular: of, relating to, or situated between an atrium and ventricle
complete: characterized by the occurrence of a pupal stage between the motile immature stages and the adult
endocarditis: inflammation of the lining of the heart and its valves
ventriculitis: inflammation of the ventricles of the brain
exudates: exuded matter; especially : the material composed of serum, fibrin, and white blood cells that escapes from blood vessels into a superficial lesion or area of inflammation
field: an area or division of an activity
8: a derivative of quinoline that is used especially in the form of its sulfate (C9H7NO)2·H2SO4 as a disinfectant, topical antiseptic, antiperspirant, and deodorant —called also oxine, oxyquinoline
enterobacter: a genus of aerobic gram-negative bacteria of the family Enterobacteriaceae that produce acid and gas from many sugars (as dextrose and lactose), form acetoin, are widely distributed in nature (as in feces, soil, water, and the contents of human and animal intestines), and include some that may be pathogenic
pacemaker: a group of cells or a body part (as the sinoatrial node of the heart) that serves to establish and maintain a rhythmic activity
frustration: a deep chronic sense or state of insecurity and dissatisfaction arising from unresolved problems or unfulfilled needs
herpetic: of, relating to, or resembling herpes
bullous: resembling or characterized by bullae : vesicular
viscosity: the quality of being viscous; especially : the property of resistance to flow in a fluid or semifluid
stupor: a condition of greatly dulled or completely suspended sense or sensibility; specifically : a chiefly mental condition marked by absence of spontaneous movement, greatly diminished responsiveness to stimulation, and usually impaired consciousness
dissection: the act or process of dissecting or separating: as
peripartum: occurring in or being the period preceding or following childbirth
essential: being, relating to, or containing an essence
nephrotic: of, relating to, affected by, or associated with nephrosis
dental: relating to, specializing in, or used in dentistry
caries: a progressive destruction of bone or tooth; especially : tooth decay
common: formed of or dividing into two or more branches
variable: able or apt to vary : subject to variation or changes
full: fully developed : being in its most extreme or serious form : possessing or exhibiting the characteristic symptoms
vulvovaginitis: coincident inflammation of the vulva and vagina
matter: material (as feces or urine) discharged or for discharge from the living body
pre-eclampsia: a serious condition developing in late pregnancy that is characterized by a sudden rise in blood pressure, excessive weight gain, generalized edema, proteinuria, severe headache, and visual disturbances and that may result in eclampsia if untreated
twin: born with one other or as a pair at one birth
skull: the skeleton of the head forming a bony case that encloses and protects the brain and chief sense organs and supports the jaws
troponin: a protein of muscle that together with tropomyosin forms a regulatory protein complex controlling the interaction of actin and myosin and that when combined with calcium ions permits muscular contraction
expansion: the act or process of expanding
peak: a device that measures the maximum rate of air flow out of the lungs during forced expiration and that is used especially for monitoring lung capacity of individuals with asthma (as to indicate bronchial narrowing) called also peak expiratory flow meter
shunt: to divert by or as if by a shunt; especially : to divert (blood or other bodily fluid) from one part to another by a surgical shunt
acinetobacter: a genus of nonmotile, gram-negative bacteria (family Moraxellaceae) that are short rods typically growing in pairs or in chains, that occur in soil and water, and that are associated with opportunistic infections especially of the skin, lungs, and urinary tract
palmoplantar: of, relating to, or affecting both the palms of the hands and the soles of the feet
keratoderma: a horny condition of the skin
nodal: being, relating to, or located at or near a node
drainage: the act or process of drawing off fluids from a cavity or wound by means of suction or gravity
aversion: a feeling of repugnance toward something with a desire to avoid or turn from it
susceptibility: the quality or state of being susceptible : the state of being predisposed to, sensitive to, or of lacking the ability to resist something (as a pathogen, familial disease, or a drug) : sensitivity
male: an individual that produces small usually motile gametes (as sperm or spermatozoa) which fertilize the eggs of a female
reproductive: of, relating to, functioning in, or capable of reproduction
testicular: of, relating to, or derived from the testes
thorax: the part of the body in vertebrates that is situated between the neck and the abdomen and supported by the ribs, costal cartilages, and sternum
tracheal: of, relating to, or functioning in the manner of a trachea : resembling a trachea
myoclonic: of, relating to, characterized by, or being myoclonus
marks: a narrow deep hollow on the surface of the crown of a horse's incisor tooth that gradually becomes obliterated by the wearing away of the crown and therefore is indicative of the animal's age and usually disappears from the lower central incisors about the sixth year while traces may remain in the upper until the eleventh
clonal: the aggregate of genetically identical cells or organisms asexually produced by a single progenitor cell or organism
evolution: a process of change in a certain direction
child: an unborn or recently born person
asymptomatic: not causing, marked by, or presenting with signs or symptoms of infection, illness, or disease
bacteriuria: the presence of bacteria in the urine
petit: a law in physics and chemistry: the specific heats of most solid elements multiplied by their atomic weights are nearly the same averaging a little over six calories per degree Celsius per gram-atomic weight
degenerative: of, relating to, involving, or tending to cause degeneration
identified: to determine the taxonomic position of (a biological specimen)
wrist: the joint or the region of the joint between the human hand and the arm or a corresponding part on a lower animal
periorbital: of, relating to, occurring in, or being the tissues surrounding or lining the orbit of the eye
hereditary: genetically transmitted or transmittable from parent to offspring
deconditioning: a decrease in the responsiveness of heart muscle that sometimes occurs after long periods of weightlessness and may be marked by decrease in blood volume and pooling of the blood in the legs upon return to normal conditions
contamination: a process of contaminating : a state of being contaminated
enterovirus: a genus of single-stranded RNA viruses of the family Picornaviridae that multiply especially in the gastrointestinal tracts of humans and swine but may infect other tissues (as nerve and muscle), that may produce clinically evident conjunctivitis, encephalitis, meningitis, myelitis, or myocarditis, and that include the poliovirus and several species including numerous serotypes named as Coxsackieviruses and echoviruses
rhinovirus: any of a genus (Rhinovirus) of single-stranded RNA viruses of the family Picornaviridae including two species (Human rhinovirus A and Human rhinovirus B) having numerous serotypes that cause respiratory infections (as the common cold) in humans
pustular: of, relating to, or resembling pustules
myopia: a condition in which the visual images come to a focus in front of the retina of the eye because of defects in the refractive media of the eye or of abnormal length of the eyeball resulting especially in defective vision of distant objects called also nearsightedness
melanosis: a condition characterized by abnormal deposition of melanins or sometimes other pigments in the tissues of the body
antral: of or relating to an antrum
ectasia: the expansion of a hollow or tubular organ
flat: being or characterized by a horizontal line or tracing without peaks or depressions
derealisation: a feeling of altered reality that occurs often in schizophrenia and in some drug reactions
drop: the quantity of fluid that falls in one spherical mass
attacks: to begin to affect or to act on injuriously
organic: of, relating to, or arising in a bodily organ
arthrodesis: the surgical immobilization of a joint so that the bones grow solidly together : artificial ankylosis
microangiopathic: a disease of very fine blood vessels
dyslexia: a variable often familial learning disability that involves difficulties in acquiring and processing language and that is typically manifested by a lack of proficiency in reading, spelling, and writing
perineal: of or relating to the perineum
evacuation: the act or process of evacuating
periodontitis: inflammation of the periodontium and especially chronic inflammation that typically follows untreated gingivitis and that results in progressive destruction of the periodontal ligament, formation of pockets around the teeth, and resorption of alveolar bone chiefly in a horizontal direction with loosening or loss of teeth called also pericementitis
schizoaffective: relating to, characterized by, or exhibiting symptoms of both schizophrenia and a mood disorder (such as major depression or bipolar disorder)
action: the process of exerting a force or bringing about an effect that results from the inherent capacity of an agent
enteroviral: a genus of single-stranded RNA viruses of the family Picornaviridae that multiply especially in the gastrointestinal tracts of humans and swine but may infect other tissues (as nerve and muscle), that may produce clinically evident conjunctivitis, encephalitis, meningitis, myelitis, or myocarditis, and that include the poliovirus and several species including numerous serotypes named as Coxsackieviruses and echoviruses
murmur: an atypical sound of the heart typically indicating a functional or structural abnormality called also heart murmur
clearing: to render (a specimen for microscopic examination) transparent by the use of an agent (as an essential oil) that modifies the index of refraction
myelitis: inflammation of the spinal cord or of the bone marrow
functional: of, connected with, or being a function
hyperuricaemia: excess uric acid in the blood (as in gout) called also uricacidemia, uricemia
pseudomonal: of, relating to, or caused by bacteria of the genus Pseudomonas
starvation: the act or an instance of starving
conjunctiva: the mucous membrane that lines the inner surface of the eyelids and is continued over the forepart of the eyeball
symblepharon: adhesion between an eyelid and the eyeball
deposit: to lay down or foster the accumulation of as a deposit
scleral: of or relating to the sclera
peritoneum: the smooth transparent serous membrane that lines the cavity of the abdomen of a mammal, is folded inward over the abdominal and pelvic viscera, and consists of an outer layer closely adherent to the walls of the abdomen and an inner layer that folds to invest the viscera
vasospasm: sharp and often persistent contraction of a blood vessel reducing its caliber and blood flow
pityriasis: any of several skin diseases marked by the formation and desquamation of fine scales
jarisch-herxheimer: an increase in the symptoms of a spirochetal disease (as syphilis, Lyme disease, or relapsing fever) occurring in some persons when treatment with spirocheticidal drugs is started called also Herxheimer reaction
epispadias: a congenital defect in which the urethra opens upon the upper surface of the penis
vesicular: characterized by the presence or formation of vesicles
nocturia: urination at night especially when excessive called also nycturia
spirometry: measurement by means of a spirometer of the volume of air entering and leaving the lungs (as to determine lung function in diagnosing pulmonary disease)
abrasion: wearing, grinding, or rubbing away by friction
aid: the act of helping or treating; also : the help or treatment given
mania: excitement of psychotic proportions manifested by mental and physical hyperactivity, disorganization of behavior, and elevation of mood; specifically : the manic phase of bipolar disorder
tinea: any of several fungal diseases of the skin; especially : ringworm
cryptitis: inflammation of a crypt (as an anal crypt)
hyperphagia: abnormally increased appetite for food frequently associated with injury to the hypothalamus
hunger: a craving, desire, or urgent need for food
hypoventilation: deficient ventilation of the lungs that results in reduction in the oxygen content or increase in the carbon dioxide content of the blood or both
meconium: a dark greenish mass of desquamated cells, mucus, and bile that accumulates in the bowel of a fetus and is typically discharged shortly after birth
parkinsonian: of or similar to that of parkinsonism
strain: a group of presumed common ancestry with clear-cut physiological but usually not morphological distinctions
mediastinal: of, relating to, or affecting the mediastinum
lysis: the gradual decline of a disease process (as fever)
implantation: the act or process of implanting or the state of being implanted: as
regional: of, relating to, or affecting a particular bodily region : localized
fibula: the outer or postaxial and usually the smaller of the two bones of the hind or lower limb below the knee that is the slenderest bone of the human body in proportion to its length, articulates above with the external tuberosity of the tibia and below with the talus, and has its lower end forming the external malleolus of the ankle called also calf bone
plasmacytoma: a myeloma composed of plasma cells
suture: a stitch made with a suture
anorectal: of, relating to, or involving both the anus and rectum
hypogammaglobulinaemia: a deficiency of gamma globulins and especially antibodies in the blood; also : a state of immunological deficiency characterized by this
extraction: the act or process of extracting something
cardioversion: application of an electric shock in order to restore normal heartbeat
elbow: the joint between the human forearm and the upper arm that supports the outer curve of the arm when bent called also elbow joint
contraindication: something (as a symptom or condition) that makes a particular treatment or procedure inadvisable
urosepsis: sepsis that is caused by an infection originating in the urinary tract, is typically associated with gram-negative bacteria (as E. coli), and may become life-threatening
hypoglycaemic: of, relating to, caused by, or affected with hypoglycemia
postoperative: relating to, occurring in, or being the period following a surgical operation
duodenal: the first, shortest, and widest part of the small intestine that in humans is about 10 inches (25 centimeters) long and that extends from the pylorus to the undersurface of the liver where it descends for a variable distance and receives the bile and pancreatic ducts and then bends to the left and finally upward to join the jejunum near the second lumbar vertebra
atresia: absence or closure of a natural passage of the body
microscopic: of, relating to, or conducted with the microscope or microscopy
reactivation: the act or process of reactivating or condition of being reactivated
empty: a feeling of prolonged sadness, loss, or emptiness that is often experienced by a parent whose children have grown up and moved away from home
intercostal: situated or extending between the ribs
blepharitis: inflammation of the eyelids and especially of their margins
polymyalgia: myalgia affecting several muscle groups; specifically : polymyalgia rheumatica
normocytic: characterized by red blood cells that are normal in size and usually also in hemoglobin content
immune-mediated: resulting from the activity of the immune system : mediated by the immune response
allergies: altered bodily reactivity (as hypersensitivity) to an antigen in response to a first exposure
laryngeal: of, relating to, affecting, or used on the larynx
absence: a nonconvulsive seizure that is marked by the temporary impairment of consciousness usually manifested as a blank facial expression, that begins and ends abruptly, and that is usually unremembered afterward called also absence, petit mal, petit mal seizure
ducts: a bodily tube or vessel especially when carrying the secretion of a gland
haemodynamic: of, relating to, or involving hemodynamics
instability: the quality or state of being unstable; especially : lack of emotional or mental stability
skeletal: of, relating to, forming, attached to, or resembling a skeleton
responsiveness: the quality or state of being responsive
neuralgic: acute paroxysmal pain radiating along the course of one or more nerves usually without demonstrable changes in the nerve structure
anosmia: loss or impairment of the sense of smell
polyomavirus: a genus of double-stranded DNA viruses (family Polyomaviridae) that contain a single molecule of DNA, have a capsid composed of 72 capsomers, and induce tumors usually in specific mammals and that include simian virus 40 and the causative agent of progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy
paranasal: adjacent to the nasal cavities; especially : of, relating to, or affecting the paranasal sinuses
chorea: a movement disorder marked by involuntary spasmodic movements especially of the limbs and facial muscles and typically symptomatic of neurological dysfunction (as that associated with a neurodegenerative disease or metabolic disturbance)
transitional: of, relating to, or characterized by transition
hallucinations,: a sensory perception (as a visual image or a sound) that occurs in the absence of an actual external stimulus and usually arises from neurological disturbance (as that associated with delirium tremens, Lewy body disease, schizophrenia, Parkinson's disease, or narcolepsy) or in response to drugs (as LSD or phencyclidine)
dispensed: to put up (a prescription or medicine)
dengue: an acute infectious disease that is characterized by headache, severe joint pain, and a rash and that is caused by a single-stranded RNA virus of the genus Flavivirus (species Dengue virus) transmitted by mosquitoes of the genus Aedes called also breakbone fever, dandy fever, dengue fever
echocardiogram: a visual record made by echocardiography; also : the procedure for producing such a record
ageusia: the absence or impairment of the sense of taste
metals: any of various opaque, fusible, ductile, and typically lustrous substances that are good conductors of electricity and heat, form cations by loss of electrons, and yield basic oxides and hydroxides; especially : one that is a chemical element as distinguished from an alloy
self-medication: medication of oneself especially without the advice of a physician : self-treatment
hyperglycaemic: an excess of sugar in the blood
hyperosmolar: the condition especially of a bodily fluid of having abnormally high osmolarity
uric: of, relating to, or found in urine
peptic: relating to or promoting digestion : digestive
marasmus: severe malnutrition affecting infants and children especially of impoverished regions that is characterized by poor growth, loss of subcutaneous fat, muscle atrophy, apathy, and pronounced weight loss and is usually caused by a diet deficient in calories and proteins but sometimes by disease (as dysentery or giardiasis)
g: a unit of force equal to the force exerted by gravity on a body at rest and used to indicate the force to which a body is subjected when accelerated
onychomadesis: loosening and shedding of the nails
anti-neutrophil: any of a group of autoantibodies that bind to cytoplasmic regions of neutrophils and are associated with diseases (such as granulomatosis with polyangiitis, Churg-Strauss syndrome, and polyarteritis nodosa) characterized by inflammation of small blood vessels abbreviation ANCA
cytoplasmic: the organized complex of inorganic and organic substances external to the nuclear membrane of a cell and including the cytosol and membrane-bound organelles (as mitochondria or chloroplasts)
clearance: the volume of blood or plasma that could be freed of a specified constituent in a specified time (usually one minute) by excretion of the constituent into the urine through the kidneys called also renal clearance
exudate: exuded matter; especially : the material composed of serum, fibrin, and white blood cells that escapes from blood vessels into a superficial lesion or area of inflammation
gland: a cell, group of cells, or organ of endothelial origin that selectively removes materials from the blood, concentrates or alters them, and secretes them for further use in the body or for elimination from the body
nephrectomy: the surgical removal of a kidney
hyperextension: to extend so that the angle between bones of a joint is greater than normal; also : to extend (as a body part) beyond the normal range of motion
cogwheel: muscular rigidity in which passive movement of the limbs (as during a physical examination) elicits ratchet-like start-and stop movements through the range of motion of a joint (as of the elbow) and that occurs especially in individuals affected with Parkinson's disease called also cogwheeling
persecutory: of, relating to, or being feelings of persecution : paranoid
pleurisy: inflammation of the pleura that is typically characterized by sudden onset, painful and difficult respiration, and exudation of fluid or fibrinous material into the pleural cavity called also pleuritis
consumption: a progressive wasting away of the body especially from pulmonary tuberculosis
support: to hold up or serve as a foundation or prop for
mineral: a solid homogeneous crystalline chemical element or compound that results from the inorganic processes of nature
supplementation: to add a supplement to : serve as a supplement for
node: a pathological swelling or enlargement (as of a rheumatic joint)
ectrodactyly: congenital complete or partial absence of one or more fingers or toes and especially the middle digits that is inherited as an autosomal dominant or recessive trait or an X-linked recessive trait or that may occur as a spontaneous mutation
subcutaneous: being, living, used, or made under the skin
saliva: a slightly alkaline secretion of water, mucin, protein, salts, and often a starch-splitting enzyme (as ptyalin) that is secreted into the mouth by salivary glands, lubricates ingested food, and often begins the breakdown of starches
adenocarcinoma: a malignant tumor originating in glandular epithelium
metaplasia: transformation of one tissue into another
carditis: inflammation of the heart muscle : myocarditis
oesophagus: a muscular tube that in adult humans is about nine inches (23 centimeters) long and passes from the pharynx down the neck between the trachea and the spinal column and behind the left bronchus where it pierces the diaphragm slightly to the left of the middle line and joins the cardiac end of the stomach
compartment: a painful condition resulting from the expansion or overgrowth of enclosed tissue (as of a leg muscle) within its anatomical enclosure (as a muscular sheath) producing pressure that interferes with circulation and adversely affects the function and health of the tissue itself called also compartmental syndrome
sarcoidosis: a chronic disease of unknown cause that is characterized by the formation of nodules resembling true tubercles especially in the lymph nodes, lungs, bones, and skin called also Boeck's disease, Boeck's sarcoid, lupus pernio
spondylolisthesis: forward displacement of a lumbar vertebra on the one below it and especially of the fifth lumbar vertebra on the sacrum producing pain by compression of nerve roots
mastication: to grind, crush, and chew (food) with or as if with the teeth in preparation for swallowing
new: a drug that has not been declared safe and effective by qualified experts under the conditions prescribed, recommended, or suggested in the label and that may be a new chemical formula or an established drug prescribed for use in a new way
onset: the initial existence or symptoms of a disease
after: an oral drug typically containing high doses of estrogen that is taken up to usually three days after unprotected sexual intercourse or contraceptive failure to prevent or delay ovulation
myoglobin: a red iron-containing protein pigment in muscles that is similar to hemoglobin but differs in the globin portion of its molecule, in the smaller size of its molecule (as in the mammalian heart muscle which has only one fourth the molecular weight of the hemoglobin in the blood of the same animal), in its greater tendency to combine with oxygen, and in its absorption of light at longer wavelengths called also myohemoglobin
remission: a state or period during which the symptoms of a disease are abated
photopsia: the perception of light (as luminous rays or flashes) that is purely subjective and accompanies a pathological condition especially of the retina or brain
bursa: a bodily pouch or sac: as
shape: to modify (behavior) by rewarding changes that tend toward a desired response
granular: consisting of or containing granules : having a grainy texture
lymphocytosis: an increase in the number of lymphocytes in the blood usually associated with chronic infections or inflammations
hydrocele: an accumulation of serous fluid in a sacculated cavity (as the scrotum)
conduction: transmission through or by means of a conductor; also : the transfer of heat through matter by communication of kinetic energy from particle to particle with no net displacement of the particles
polymyositis: inflammation of several muscles at once; specifically : an inflammatory disease of unknown cause that affects muscles and especially skeletal muscles, is characterized typically by weakness usually of the proximal muscles (such as those of the shoulder or pelvic girdles or of the neck), muscle and joint pain, pathological muscle changes (such as fiber degeneration or infiltration by lymphocytes), pneumonia, and cardiac abnormalities (such as arrhythmia or myocarditis)
short-bowel: malabsorption from the small intestine that is marked by diarrhea, malnutrition, and steatorrhea and that results from resection of the small intestine
paronychia: inflammation of the tissues adjacent to the nail of a finger or toe usually accompanied by infection and pus formation
hair: a slender threadlike outgrowth of the epidermis of an animal; especially : one of the usually pigmented filaments that form the characteristic coat of a mammal
hyperpigmentation: excess pigmentation in a body part or tissue (as the skin)
gravis: tending to be more virulent than average used especially of strains of diphtheria bacilli
salmonellosis: infection with or disease caused by bacteria of the genus Salmonella typically marked by gastroenteritis but often complicated by septicemia, meningitis, endocarditis, and various focal lesions (as in the kidneys)
haemorrhoidal: of, relating to, or involving hemorrhoids
gastroenterostomy: the surgical formation of a passage between the stomach and small intestine
stomach: a saclike expansion of the digestive tract of a vertebrate communicating anteriorly with the esophagus and posteriorly with the duodenum and being typically a simple often curved sac with an outer serous coat, a strong complex muscular wall that contracts rhythmically, and a mucous lining membrane that contains gastric glands
gastrectomy: surgical removal of all or part of the stomach
lymphadenectomy: surgical removal of a lymph node
et: to take in through the mouth as food : ingest, chew, and swallow in turn
anovulatory: not involving or associated with ovulation
cycle: a recurring series of events: as
menstruation: a discharging of blood, secretions, and tissue debris from the uterus that recurs in nonpregnant human and other primate females of breeding age at approximately monthly intervals and that is considered to represent a readjustment of the uterus to the nonpregnant state following proliferative changes accompanying the preceding ovulation; also : period
dystonia: a state of disordered tonicity of tissues (as of muscle)
cachexia: general physical wasting and malnutrition usually associated with chronic disease
homosexuality: sexual or romantic attraction to others of one's same sex : the quality or state of being gay
intake: the act or process of taking in
corona: the upper portion of a bodily part (as a tooth or the skull)
dysphemia: a speech disorder characterized especially by stammering or stuttering and usually having a psychological basis
gynaecomastia: excessive development of the breast in the male
meningococcal: a bacterium of the genus Neisseria (N. meningitidis) that causes cerebrospinal meningitis
antinuclear: being antibodies or autoantibodies that react with components and especially DNA of cell nuclei and that tend to occur frequently in connective tissue diseases (as systemic lupus erythematosus, rheumatoid arthritis, and Sjgrens syndrome)
chemicals: a substance (as an element or chemical compound) obtained by a chemical process or used for producing a chemical effect
catheter: a tubular medical device for insertion into canals, vessels, passageways, or body cavities for diagnostic or therapeutic purposes (as to permit injection or withdrawal of fluids or to keep a passage open)
management: the whole system of care and treatment of a disease or a sick individual
intraocular: implanted in, occurring within, or administered by entering the eyeball
wrinkling: to become marked with or contracted into wrinkles
megaloblastic: a large erythroblast that appears in the blood especially in pernicious anemia
cytokine: any of a class of immunoregulatory proteins (as interleukin, tumor necrosis factor, and interferon) that are secreted by cells especially of the immune system
release: designed to slowly release a drug in the body in a prolonged controlled fashion; also : sustained-release
bradykinesia: extreme slowness of movements and reflexes (such as that caused by Parkinson's disease or antipsychotic drugs)
neurone: one of the cells that constitute nervous tissue, that have the property of transmitting and receiving nerve impulses, and that are composed of somewhat reddish or grayish protoplasm with a large nucleus containing a conspicuous nucleolus, irregular cytoplasmic granules, and cytoplasmic processes which are highly differentiated frequently as multiple dendrites or usually as solitary axons and which conduct impulses toward and away from the cell body : nerve cell
b6: pyridoxine or a closely related compound found widely in combined form and considered essential to vertebrate nutrition
pupils: the contractile usually round aperture in the iris of the eye
polyglandular: of, relating to, or involving several glands
erection: the state marked by firm turgid form and erect or elevated position of a previously flaccid bodily part containing cavernous tissue when that tissue becomes dilated with blood
volvulus: a twisting of the intestine upon itself that causes obstruction
mechanical: relating to the quantitative relations of force and matter
alveolar: of, relating to, resembling, or having alveoli
helicobacter: a genus of bacteria formerly placed in the genus Campylobacter and including one (H. pylori) associated with gastritis and implicated as a causative agent of gastric and duodenal ulcers
megacolon: extreme dilation of the colon that may be congenital or acquired
ingrown: grown in; specifically : having the normally free tip or edge embedded in the flesh
cortisol: a glucocorticoid C21H30O5 produced by the adrenal cortex upon stimulation by ACTH that mediates various metabolic processes (as gluconeogenesis), has anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive properties, and whose levels in the blood may become elevated in response to physical or psychological stress called also hydrocortisone
sex: either of the two major forms of individuals that occur in many species and that are distinguished respectively as male or female especially on the basis of their reproductive organs and structures
dehydroepiandrosterone: an androgenic ketosteroid C19H28O2 secreted by the adrenal cortex that is an intermediate in the biosynthesis of testosterone abbreviation DHA, DHEA
focal: of, relating to, being, or having a focus
deviation: an act or instance of diverging from an established way or in a new direction: as
aura: a subjective sensation (as of voices or colored lights or crawling and numbness) experienced at the onset of a neurological condition and especially a migraine or epileptic seizure
sickness: the condition of being ill : ill health
screen: to test or examine for the presence of something (as a disease)
thinning: a drug used to prevent the formation of blood clots by hindering coagulation of the blood
thymus: a glandular structure of largely lymphoid tissue that functions in cell-mediated immunity by being the site where T cells develop, that is present in the young of most vertebrates typically in the upper anterior chest or at the base of the neck, that arises from the epithelium of one or more embryonic branchial clefts, and that gradually decreases in size and activity after puberty
mediastinum: the space in the chest between the pleural sacs of the lungs that contains all the viscera of the chest except the lungs and pleurae; also : this space with its contents
pituitary: of or relating to the pituitary gland
hypopnoea: abnormally slow or especially shallow respiration
repair: to restore to a sound or healthy state
parvovirus: a genus of single-stranded DNA viruses of the family Parvoviridae that includes the causative agents of panleukopenia in cats and fifth disease in humans
section: the action or an instance of cutting or separating by cutting; especially : the action of dividing (as tissues) surgically
normal: conforming to a type, standard, or regular pattern : characterized by that which is considered usual, typical, or routine
haemosiderosis: excessive deposition of hemosiderin in bodily tissues as a result of the breakdown of red blood cells
cavitation: the process of cavitating; especially : the formation of cavities in an organ or tissue especially in disease
fissure: a natural cleft between body parts or in the substance of an organ: as
dermal: of or relating to skin and especially to the dermis : cutaneous
chloasma: irregular brownish or blackish spots especially on the face that occur sometimes in pregnancy and in disorders of or functional changes in the uterus and ovaries
ejaculation: the act or process of ejaculating; specifically : the sudden or spontaneous discharging of a fluid (as semen in orgasm) from a duct
cd4: a large glycoprotein that is found associated with a T cell receptor especially on the surface of helper T cells and that binds to a major histocompatibility complex molecule on the surface of an antigen-presenting cell to facilitate antigen recognition and T cell activation often used before another noun
lymphocytes: any of the colorless weakly motile cells that originate from stem cells and differentiate in lymphoid tissue (as of the thymus or bone marrow), that are the typical cellular elements of lymph, that include the cellular mediators of immunity, and that constitute 20 to 30 percent of the white blood cells of normal human blood
segmental: of, relating to, or having the form of a segment
family: the basic unit in society traditionally consisting of two parents rearing their children; also : any of various social units differing from but regarded as equivalent to the traditional family
occult: not manifest or detectable by clinical methods alone; also : not present in macroscopic amounts
hyperkeratosis: hypertrophy of the stratum corneum layer of the skin
bacillary: shaped like a rod; also : consisting of small rods
angiomatosis: a condition characterized by the formation of multiple angiomas
mastectomy: surgical removal of all or part of the breast and sometimes associated lymph nodes and muscles
sacrum: the part of the spinal column that is directly connected with or forms a part of the pelvis by articulation with the ilia and that in humans forms the dorsal wall of the pelvis and consists of five fused vertebrae diminishing in size to the apex at the lower end which bears the coccyx
persistent: existing or continuing for a long time: as
reconstruction: repair of an organ or part by reconstructive surgery
nystagmus: involuntary usually rapid movement of the eyeballs (as from side to side) occurring normally with dizziness during and after bodily rotation or abnormally following head injury or as a symptom of disease
vasodilatation: widening of the lumen of blood vessels
hard: not easily penetrated : not easily yielding to pressure
ecchymosis: the escape of blood into the tissues from ruptured blood vessels marked by a livid black-and-blue or purple spot or area; also : the discoloration so caused
tachyarrhythmia: arrhythmia characterized by a rapid irregular heartbeat
fanconi: aplastic anemia that is inherited as an autosomal recessive trait and is characterized by progressive pancytopenia, hypoplastic bone marrow, skeletal anomalies (as short stature), microcephaly, hypogonadism, and a predisposition to leukemia
mycoplasmal: the type genus of the family Mycoplasmataceae containing minute pleomorphic gram-negative chiefly nonmotile bacteria that are mostly parasitic usually in mammals
osteosarcoma: a sarcoma derived from bone or containing bone tissue called also osteogenic sarcoma
annuloplasty: surgical treatment of a ringlike anatomical part; specifically : surgical repair of a heart valve that typically involves reducing the diameter of the valve's fibrous ring
replacement: therapy involving the supplying of something (as nutrients or blood) lacking from or lost to the system
open: having the skin cracked, cut, or broken so that underlying tissue is exposed
pseudomonas: a genus (the type of the family Pseudomonadaceae) comprising short rod-shaped motile gram-negative bacteria including some saprophytes, a few animal pathogens, and numerous important plant pathogens
evisceration: the act or process of eviscerating
intensive: of, relating to, or marked by an extreme degree especially of dosage, duration, or frequency
unit: an amount of a biologically active agent (as a drug or antigen) required to produce a specific result under strictly controlled conditions
excipient: a usually inert substance (as gum arabic, syrup, lanolin, or starch) that forms a vehicle (as for a drug or antigen); especially : one that in the presence of sufficient liquid gives a medicated mixture the adhesive quality needed for the preparation of pills or tablets
cryptococcosis: an infectious disease that is caused by a fungus of the genus Cryptococcus (C. neoformans) and is characterized by the production of nodular lesions or abscesses in subcutaneous tissues, joints, and especially the lungs, brain, and meninges and often by pneumonia or meningitis called also torulosis
flutter: an abnormal rapid spasmodic and usually rhythmic motion or contraction of a body part
metatarsalgia: a cramping burning pain below and between the metatarsal bones where they join the toe bones
infarct: an area of necrosis in a tissue or organ resulting from obstruction of the local circulation by a thrombus or embolus
amyotrophic: relating to or marked by amyotrophia
lateral: of or relating to the side; especially, of a body part : lying at or extending toward the right or left side : lying away from the median axis of the body
frequency: the number of individuals in a single class when objects are classified according to variations in a set of one or more specified attributes
campylobacter: a genus of slender spirally curved rod bacteria of the family Spirillaceae that are gram-negative, microaerophilic, and motile with a characteristic motion resembling a corkscrew, that do not form spores, and that include forms formerly included in the genus Spirillum or Vibrio of which some are pathogenic for domestic animals or humans
chorioretinal: of, relating to, or affecting the choroid and the retina of the eye
posture: the position or bearing of the body whether characteristic or assumed for a special purpose
anhedonia: a psychological condition characterized by inability to experience pleasure in acts which normally produce it
orgasmic: the climax of sexual excitement that is usually accompanied by ejaculation of semen in the male and by vaginal contractions in the female
penile: of, relating to, or affecting the penis
sensitisation: the action or process of making sensitive or hypersensitive
caffeine: a bitter alkaloid C8H10N4O2 found especially in coffee, tea, and kola nuts and used medicinally as a stimulant and diuretic
vital: existing as a manifestation of life
larynx: the modified upper part of the respiratory passage of air-breathing vertebrates that is bounded above by the glottis, is continuous below with the trachea, has a complex cartilaginous or bony skeleton capable of limited motion through the action of associated muscles, and in humans, most other mammals, and a few lower forms has a set of elastic vocal cords that play a major role in sound production and speech called also voice box
smoke: to inhale and exhale the fumes of burning plant material and especially tobacco; especially : to smoke tobacco habitually
water: the liquid that descends from the clouds as rain, forms streams, lakes, and seas, and is a major constituent of all living matter and that is an odorless, tasteless, very slightly compressible liquid oxide of hydrogen H2O which appears bluish in thick layers, freezes at 0°C (32°F) and boils at 100°C (212°F), has a maximum density at 4°C (39°F) and a high specific heat, is feebly ionized to hydrogen and hydroxyl ions, and is a poor conductor of electricity and a good solvent
intoxication: an abnormal state that is essentially a poisoning
logorrhoea: pathologically excessive and often incoherent talkativeness or wordiness that is characteristic especially of the manic phase of bipolar disorder
connection: any of various instruments or appliances having parts brought together for holding or compressing something; especially : an instrument used to hold, compress, or crush vessels and hollow organs and to aid in surgical excision of parts
recalled: remembrance of what has been previously learned or experienced
spasm: an involuntary and abnormal contraction of muscle or muscle fibers or of a hollow organ (as an artery, the colon, or the esophagus) that consists largely of involuntary muscle fibers
folliculitis: inflammation of one or more follicles especially of the hair
leiomyoma: a benign tumor (as a fibroid) consisting of smooth muscle fibers
catecholamine: any of various amines (as epinephrine, norepinephrine, and dopamine) that contain a dihydroxy benzene ring, that are derived from tyrosine, and that function as hormones or neurotransmitters or both
craniopharyngioma: a tumor of the brain near the pituitary gland that develops especially in children or young adults from epithelium derived from the embryonic craniopharyngeal canal and that is often associated with increased intracranial pressure
purulent: containing, consisting of, or being pus
sciatica: pain along the course of a sciatic nerve especially in the back of the thigh caused by compression, inflammation, or reflex mechanisms; broadly : pain in the lower back, buttocks, hips, or adjacent parts
fungaemia: the presence of fungi (as yeasts) in the blood
mycosis: infection with or disease caused by a fungus
asthenopia: weakness or rapid fatigue of the eyes often accompanied by pain and headache
salmonella: a genus of aerobic gram-negative rod-shaped nonspore-forming usually motile bacteria of the family Enterobacteriaceae that grow well on artificial media and form acid and gas on many carbohydrates but not on lactose, sucrose, or salicin, that are pathogenic for humans and other warm-blooded animals, and that cause food poisoning, acute gastrointestinal inflammation, typhoid fever, and septicemia
fulminant: coming on suddenly with great severity
lyme: an acute inflammatory disease that is usually characterized initially by the skin lesion erythema migrans and by fatigue, fever, and chills and if left untreated may later manifest itself in cardiac and neurological disorders, joint pain, and arthritis and that is caused by a spirochete of the genus Borrelia (B. burgdorferi) transmitted by the bite of a tick especially of the genus Ixodes (I. scapularis synonym I. dammini in the eastern and midwestern United States, I. pacificus especially in some parts of the Pacific coastal states of the United States, and I. ricinus in Europe) called also Lyme, Lyme borreliosis
temporal: of or relating to time as distinguished from space; also : of or relating to the sequence of time or to a particular time
terror: a sudden awakening in dazed terror that occurs in children during slow-wave sleep, is often preceded by a sudden shrill cry uttered in sleep, and is not remembered when the child awakes usually used in pluralcalled also pavor nocturnus
clonus: a series of alternating contractions and partial relaxations of a muscle that in some diseases of the central nervous system occurs in the form of convulsive spasms involving complex groups of muscles and is believed to result from alteration of the normal pattern of motor neuron discharge
hypercalciuria: the presence of an excess amount of calcium in the urine
alveolitis: inflammation of one or more alveoli especially of the lung
opacity: the quality or state of a body that makes it impervious to the rays of light; broadly : the relative capacity of matter to obstruct by absorption or reflection the transmission of radiant energy (as X-rays, infrared radiation, or sound)
galactorrhoea: a spontaneous flow of milk from the nipple
deficit: a deficiency of a substance; also : a lack or impairment of a functional capacity
polyradiculoneuropathy: an inflammatory disorder (as Guillain-Barr syndrome) affecting peripheral nerves and the nerve roots of the spinal nerves and marked by demyelination or axon degeneration
instillation: an act of instilling : introduction by instilling
residual: of, relating to, or being something that remains: as
autism: a developmental disorder that appears by age three and that is variable in expression but is recognized and diagnosed by impairment of the ability to form normal social relationships, by impairment of the ability to communicate with others, and by stereotyped behavior patterns especially as exhibited by a preoccupation with repetitive activities of restricted focus rather than with flexible and imaginative ones called also autistic disorder
spectrum: a continuum of color formed when a beam of white light is dispersed (as by passage through a prism) so that its component wavelengths are arranged in order
transformation: an act, process, or instance of transforming or being transformed
herniation: the act or process of herniating
motility: the quality or state of being motile : capability of movement
rheumatic: of, relating to, characteristic of, or affected with rheumatism
septal: of or relating to a septum
hyperpyrexia: exceptionally high fever (as in a particular disease)
invasive: tending to spread; especially : tending to invade healthy tissue
ductal: of or belonging to a duct : made up of ducts
endoscopy: an illuminated usually fiber-optic flexible or rigid tubular instrument for visualizing the interior of a hollow organ or part (as the bladder or esophagus) for diagnostic or therapeutic purposes that typically has one or more channels to enable passage of instruments (as forceps or scissors)
osteosclerosis: abnormal hardening of bone or of bone marrow
development: the action or process of developing: as
alcohol: ethanol especially when considered as the intoxicating agent in fermented and distilled liquors
neurotransmitter: a substance (as norepinephrine or acetylcholine) that transmits nerve impulses across a synapse
wheelchair: a chair mounted on wheels especially for the use of disabled individuals
diplegia: paralysis of corresponding parts (as the legs) on both sides of the body
antiphospholipid: relating to or being an antibody (such as anticardiolipin antibody) that acts against phospholipids or proteins that bind to phospholipids and is associated with antiphospholipid syndrome
antibodies: any of a large number of proteins of high molecular weight that are produced normally by specialized B cells after stimulation by an antigen and act specifically against the antigen in an immune response, that are produced abnormally by some cancer cells, and that typically consist of four subunits including two heavy chains and two light chains called also immunoglobulin
hyperchloraemic: the presence of excess chloride ions in the blood
defective: falling below the norm in structure or function
humerus: the longest bone of the upper arm or forelimb extending from the shoulder to the elbow, articulating above by a rounded head with the glenoid cavity, having below a broad articular surface divided by a ridge into a medial pulley-shaped portion and a lateral rounded eminence that articulate with the ulna and radius respectively, and providing various processes and modified surfaces for the attachment of muscles
hiatus: a gap or passage through an anatomical part or organ; especially : an opening through which another part or organ passes (such as the opening in the diaphragm through which the esophagus and vagus nerves pass)
porokeratosis: any of several often inherited skin disorders that are characterized by the proliferation of atypical keratinocytes and is marked by the presence of usually circular atrophic skin lesions which are surrounded by a ridgelike horny border
diverticular: consisting of or resembling a diverticulum
microcephaly: a condition of abnormal smallness of the circumference of the head that is present at birth or develops within the first few years of life and is often associated with developmental delays, impaired cognitive development, poor coordination and balance, deficits in hearing and vision, and seizures
choroid: a vascular membrane containing large branched pigment cells that lies between the retina and the sclera of the eye called also choroid coat
plexus: a network of anastomosing or interlacing blood vessels or nerves
selective: of, relating to, or characterized by selection : selecting or tending to select
asthmatic: of, relating to, or affected with asthma
endometriosis: the presence and growth of tissue similar to endometrium in places other than the uterus and especially in the pelvis and abdomen and that often results in severe pain and infertility
cytogenetic: a branch of biology that deals with the study of heredity and variation by the methods of both cytology and genetics
hiv: any of several retroviruses and especially HIV-1 that infect and destroy helper T cells of the immune system causing the marked reduction in their numbers that is diagnostic of AIDS called also AIDS virus, human immunodeficiency virus
rna: any of various nucleic acids that contain ribose and uracil as structural components and are associated with the control of cellular chemical activities called also ribonucleic acid
sphincter: an annular muscle surrounding and able to contract or close a bodily opening
oddi: a complex sphincter closing the duodenal orifice of the common bile duct
psychosexual: of or relating to the mental, emotional, and behavioral aspects of sexual development
epicondylitis: inflammation of an epicondyle or of adjacent tissues
trigeminal: of or relating to the trigeminal nerve
histamine: a compound C5H9N3 especially of mammalian tissues that causes dilatation of capillaries, contraction of smooth muscle, and stimulation of gastric acid secretion, that is released during allergic reactions, and that is formed by decarboxylation of histidine
hyperlipidaemia: the presence of excess fat or lipids in the blood
xerosis: abnormal dryness of a body part or tissue (as the skin or conjunctiva)
syndactyly: a union of two or more digits that is normal in some animals and that in humans occurs as an inherited condition or as a part of several genetic disorders and is marked by webbing of two or more fingers or toes and sometimes bony fusion of adjacent digits
episcleritis: inflammation of the superficial layers of the sclera
chapped: to crack or open in slits
lips: either of the two fleshy folds which surround the opening of the mouth in humans and many other vertebrates and in humans are organs of speech essential to certain articulations; also : the pinkish or reddish margin of a human lip composed of nonglandular mucous membrane and usually exposed when the mouth takes on its natural set
lacrimal: of, relating to, associated with, located near, or constituting the glands that produce tears
leukonychia: a white spotting, streaking, or discoloration of the fingernails caused by injury or ill health
anhidrosis: abnormal deficiency or absence of sweating
cryptosporidiosis: infection with or disease caused by cryptosporidia
nitrogen: a common nonmetallic element that in the free form is normally a colorless odorless tasteless insoluble inert diatomic gas comprising 78 percent of the atmosphere by volume and that in the combined form is a constituent of biologically important compounds (as proteins, nucleic acids, and alkaloids) and hence of all living cells as well as of industrially important substances (as cyanides, fertilizers, dyes, and antibiotics) symbol N
regulation: the act of regulating; also : the resulting state or condition
weeping: to pour forth (tears) from the eyes
reconstitution: the action of reconstituting or state of being reconstituted
polydactyly: the condition of having more than the normal number of toes or fingers called also polydactylia, polydactylism
fractures: the act or process of breaking or the state of being broken; specifically : the breaking of hard tissue and especially bone
haematological: of or relating to blood or to hematology
hypersplenism: a condition marked by excessive destruction of one or more kinds of blood cells in the spleen
fluorosis: an abnormal condition (as mottled enamel of human teeth) caused by fluorine or its compounds
consolidation: the process by which an infected lung passes from an aerated collapsible condition to one of airless solid consistency through the accumulation of exudate in the alveoli and adjoining ducts; also : tissue that has undergone consolidation
intellectual: the power of knowing as distinguished from the power to feel and to will : the capacity for knowledge
neuropsychiatric: a branch of medicine concerned with both neurology and psychiatry
psychogenic: originating in the mind : attributable to psychological or emotional factors
hypospadias: an abnormality of the penis in which the urethra opens on the underside
cytology: a branch of biology dealing with the structure, function, multiplication, pathology, and life history of cells : cell biology
adrenocortical: of, relating to, or derived from the cortex of the adrenal glands
neurocysticercosis: infection of the central nervous system with cysticerci of the pork tapeworm (Taenia solium)
self: the union of elements (as body, emotions, thoughts, and sensations) that constitute the individuality and identity of a person
articular: of or relating to a joint
peeling: to strip off an outer layer of
electroencephalogram: the tracing of brain waves made by an electroencephalograph
hypercapnic: the presence of an excess of carbon dioxide in the blood
peroneal: of, relating to, or located near the fibula
hiccups: a spasmodic inhalation with closure of the glottis accompanied by a peculiar sound
stillbirth: the birth of a dead fetus
chlamydial: the type genus of the family Chlamydiaceae comprising coccoid to spherical gram-negative intracellular parasitic bacteria and including one (C. trachomatis) that causes or is associated with various diseases of the eye and genitourinary tract including trachoma, lymphogranuloma venereum, cervicitis, and some forms of nongonococcal urethritis
dysgraphia: impairment of handwriting ability that is characterized chiefly by very poor or often illegible writing or writing that takes an unusually long time and great effort to complete
fat: notable for having an unusual amount of fat; especially : fleshy with superfluous flabby tissue that is not muscle : obese
kyphosis: exaggerated outward curvature of the thoracic region of the spinal column resulting in a rounded upper back
antisocial: hostile or harmful to organized society: as
paranoid: characterized by or resembling paranoia or paranoid schizophrenia
haemoglobinuria: the presence of free hemoglobin in the urine
transferrin: a beta globulin in blood plasma capable of combining with ferric ions and transporting iron in the body called also siderophilin
colostomy: surgical formation of an artificial anus by connecting the colon to an opening in the abdominal wall
developmental: the action or process of developing: as
astigmatism: a defect of an optical system (as a lens) causing rays from a point to fail to meet in a focal point resulting in a blurred and imperfect image
onycholysis: a loosening of a nail from the nail bed beginning at the free edge and proceeding to the root
pupil: the contractile usually round aperture in the iris of the eye
fixed: to make firm, stable, or stationary
decerebrate: having the cerebrum removed or made inactive
zika: a flavivirus (species Zika virus of the genus Flavivirus) typically transmitted by mosquitoes of the genus Aedes (especially A. aegypti and A. albopictus) and that causes a usually mild illness marked chiefly by fever, joint pain, rash, and conjunctivitis and that has been associated with an increased incidence of microcephaly in infants born to pregnant women infected with the virus
psychological: relating to, characteristic of, directed toward, influencing, arising in, or acting through the mind especially in its affective or cognitive functions
trauma: an injury (as a wound) to living tissue caused by an extrinsic agent
miliaria: an inflammatory disorder of the skin characterized by redness, eruption, burning or itching, and the release of sweat in abnormal ways (as by the eruption of vesicles) due to blockage of the ducts of the sweat glands; especially : prickly heat
expectancy: the expected amount (as of the number of years of life) based on statistical probability
vibratory: of, consisting in, capable of, or causing vibration or oscillation
sense: the faculty of perceiving by means of sense organs
neuropathic: of, relating to, characterized by, or being a neuropathy
contractions: the action or process of contracting : the state of being contracted
involuntary: not subject to control of the will : reflex
myotonia: tonic spasm of one or more muscles; also : a condition characterized by such spasms
circadian: being, having, characterized by, or occurring in approximately 24-hour periods or cycles (as of biological activity or function)
rhythm: a regularly recurrent quantitative change in a variable biological process: as
orthopnoea: difficulty in breathing that occurs when lying down and is relieved upon changing to an upright position (as in congestive heart failure)
accommodation: an adaptation or adjustment especially of a bodily part (as an organ): as
senile: of, relating to, exhibiting, or characteristic of old age; especially, sometimes disparaging + offensive : exhibiting a decline of cognitive abilities (as memory) associated with old age
borderline: being in an intermediate position or state : not fully classifiable as one thing or its opposite; especially : not quite up to what is usual, standard, or expected
venoocclusive: marked by occlusion or compression of small veins
prerenal: occurring in the circulatory system before the kidney is reached
alcoholic: of, relating to, or caused by alcohol
interval: a space of time between events or states
convulsion: an abnormal violent and involuntary contraction or series of contractions of the muscles often used in plural
angle: a corner whether constituting a projecting part or a partially enclosed space
defiant: a disruptive behavior pattern of childhood and adolescence characterized by defiant, disobedient, and hostile behavior especially toward adults in positions of authority abbreviation ODD
herbal: a book about plants especially with reference to their medical properties
language: any of various formal languages employing a system of hand gestures and their placement relative to the upper body, facial expressions, body postures, and finger spelling especially for communication by and with deaf people
tophus: a deposit of urates in tissues (as cartilage) characteristic of gout
fluctuating: a motion like that of waves; especially : the wavelike motion of a fluid collected in a natural or artificial cavity of the body observed by palpation or percussion
pyuria: the presence of pus in the urine; also : a condition (as pyelonephritis) characterized by pus in the urine
superinfection: a second infection superimposed on an earlier one especially by a different microbial agent of exogenous or endogenous origin that is resistant to the treatment used against the first infection
enlarged: larger or greater than that formerly or normally present
uvula: the pendent fleshy lobe in the middle of the posterior border of the soft palate
endodontic: a branch of dentistry concerned with diseases of the pulp
keratitis: inflammation of the cornea of the eye characterized by burning or smarting, blurring of vision, and sensitiveness to light and caused by infectious or noninfectious agents called also corneitis
single: of, relating to, or being an experimental procedure in which the experimenters but not the subjects know the makeup of the test and control groups during the actual course of the experiments
hypoplastic: a condition of arrested development in which an organ or part remains below the normal size or in an immature state
acantholytic: loss of coherence between keratinocytes of the epidermis that is due to breakdown of desmosomal intercellular attachments and is characteristic of various conditions (as pemphigus and herpesvirus infection) marked by vesicular eruption
culture: the integrated pattern of human behavior that includes thought, speech, action, and artifacts and depends upon the human capacity for learning and transmitting knowledge to succeeding generations
postpartum: occurring in or being the period following childbirth
gestational: the carrying of young in the uterus from conception to delivery : pregnancy
preservatives: something that preserves or has the power of preserving; specifically : an additive used to protect against decay, discoloration, or spoilage
stimulation: the act or process of stimulating
mantle: something that covers, enfolds, or envelops
stridor: a harsh vibrating sound heard during respiration in cases of obstruction of the air passages
incompatibility: the quality or state of being incompatible
heel: the back of the human foot below the ankle and behind the arch
pad: a usually square or rectangular piece of often folded typically absorbent material (as gauze) fixed in place over some part of the body as a dressing or other protective covering
cardiorenal: of or relating to the heart and the kidneys
hydronephrosis: cystic distension of the kidney caused by the accumulation of urine in the renal pelvis as a result of obstruction to outflow and accompanied by atrophy of the kidney structure and cyst formation
urethral: the canal that in most mammals carries off the urine from the bladder and in the male serves also as a passageway for semen
abdomen: the part of the body between the thorax and the pelvis with the exception of the back called also belly
intra-abdominal: situated within, occurring within, or administered by entering the abdomen
mucormycosis: mycosis caused by fungi of the genus Mucor usually primarily involving the lungs and invading other tissues by means of metastatic lesions
deposits: matter laid down or accumulated especially in a living organism by a normal or abnormal process
silent: not exhibiting or producing the usual signs or symptoms of presence
semen: a viscid whitish fluid of the male reproductive tract consisting of spermatozoa suspended in secretions of accessory glands (as of the prostate and Cowper's glands)
selection: a natural or artificial process that results or tends to result in the survival and propagation of some individuals or organisms but not of others with the result that the inherited traits of the survivors are perpetuated
diffusion: the process whereby particles of liquids, gases, or solids intermingle as the result of their spontaneous movement caused by thermal agitation and in dissolved substances move from a region of higher to one of lower concentration
polychromasia: the quality of being polychromatic; specifically : polychromatophilia
drugs: a substance used as a medication or in the preparation of medication
affecting: to produce an effect upon; especially : to produce a material influence upon or alteration in
foetus: an unborn or unhatched vertebrate especially after attaining the basic structural plan of its kind; specifically : a developing human from usually two months after conception to birth
obsessive-compulsive: relating to or characterized by recurring obsessions and compulsions especially as symptoms of an obsessive-compulsive disorder
