hypopituitarism: deficient production of growth hormones by the pituitary gland
encephalomalacia: softening of the brain due to degenerative changes in nervous tissue (as in crazy chick disease)
dystrophy: a condition produced by faulty nutrition
animal: any of a kingdom (Animalia) of living things including many-celled organisms and often many of the single-celled ones (as protozoans) that typically differ from plants in having cells without cellulose walls, in lacking chlorophyll and the capacity for photosynthesis, in requiring more complex food materials (as proteins), in being organized to a greater degree of complexity, and in having the capacity for spontaneous movement and rapid motor response to stimulation
electrical: of, relating to, or operated by electricity
performance: a test of capacity to achieve a desired result; especially : an intelligence test (as by a maze or picture completion) requiring little use of language
patent: protected by a trademark or a trade name so as to establish proprietary rights analogous to those conveyed by a patent : proprietary
thermal: of, relating to, or caused by heat
flow: to move with a continual change of place among the constituent particles
trichotillomania: abnormal desire to pull out one's hair called also hairpulling, trich
thoracic: of, relating to, located within, or involving the thorax
packed: to cover or surround with a pack; specifically : to envelop (a patient) in a wet or dry sheet or blanket
keratoacanthoma: a rapidly growing skin tumor that occurs especially in elderly individuals, resembles a carcinoma of squamous epithelial cells but does not spread, and tends to heal spontaneously with some scarring if left untreated
guttate: having small usually colored spots or drops
overgrowth: excessive growth or increase in numbers
threshold: the point at which a physiological or psychological effect begins to be produced (as the degree of stimulation of a nerve which just produces a response or the concentration of sugar in the blood at which sugar just begins to pass the barrier of the kidneys and enter the urine) called also limen
potentiating: to make effective or active or more effective or more active; also : to augment the activity of (as a drug) synergistically
diaphragmatic: of, involving, or resembling a diaphragm
leukaemoid: resembling leukemia but not involving the same changes in the blood-forming organs
somatic: of, relating to, or affecting the body especially as distinguished from the germplasm : physical
humidity: a moderate degree of wetness especially of the atmosphere
transverse: acting, lying, or being across : set crosswise
oligomenorrhoea: abnormally infrequent or scanty menstrual flow
arteriovenous: of, relating to, or connecting the arteries and veins
molluscum: any of several skin diseases marked by soft pulpy nodules; especially : molluscum contagiosum
hirsutism: excessive growth of hair of normal or abnormal distribution : hypertrichosis
goitre: an enlargement of the thyroid gland that is commonly visible as a swelling of the anterior part of the neck, that often results from insufficient intake of iodine and then is usually accompanied by hypothyroidism, and that in other cases is associated with hyperthyroidism usually together with toxic symptoms and exophthalmos called also struma
cleft: a usually abnormal fissure or opening especially when resulting from failure of parts to fuse during embryonic development
palate: the roof of the mouth separating the mouth from the nasal cavity
pierre: a congenital defect of the face characterized by micrognathia, abnormal smallness of the tongue, cleft palate, and absence of the gag reflex and sometimes accompanied by bilateral eye defects, glaucoma, or retinal detachment
robin: a congenital defect of the face characterized by micrognathia, abnormal smallness of the tongue, cleft palate, and absence of the gag reflex and sometimes accompanied by bilateral eye defects, glaucoma, or retinal detachment
bypass: a surgically established shunt; also : a surgical procedure for the establishment of a shunt
acanthosis: a benign overgrowth of the stratum spinosum of the skin
collagen: an insoluble fibrous protein of vertebrates that is the chief constituent of the fibrils of connective tissue (as in skin and tendons) and of the organic substance of bones and yields gelatin and glue on prolonged heating with water
frostbite: to affect or injure by frost or frostbite
palliative: reducing the severity of a disease or condition without curing it : providing palliative care
paroxysmal: of, relating to, or marked by paroxysms
fractional: of, relating to, or involving a process for separating components of a mixture through differences in physical or chemical properties
nitric: of, relating to, or containing nitrogen especially with a higher valence than in corresponding nitrous compounds
oxide: a binary compound of oxygen with a more electropositive element or chemical group
nocturnal: of, relating to, or occurring at night
parasitic: relating to or having the habit of a parasite : living on another organism
multi-organ: of, involving, or affecting more than one organ
torsion: the twisting of a bodily organ or part on its own axis
vitiligo: a progressive skin disorder that is a form of leukoderma caused by the localized or generalized destruction of melanocytes and marked by sharply circumscribed white spots of skin
nephrogenic: originating in the kidney : caused by factors originating in the kidney
masked: failing to present or produce the usual symptoms : not obvious : latent
cluster: a larger than expected number of cases of disease (as leukemia) occurring in a particular locality, group of people, or period of time
postmortem: done, occurring, or collected after death
paraneoplastic: caused by or resulting from the presence of cancer in the body but not the physical presence of cancerous tissue in the part or organ affected
tetralogy: a congenital abnormality of the heart characterized by pulmonary stenosis, an opening in the interventricular septum, malposition of the aorta over both ventricles, and hypertrophy of the right ventricle
osteolysis: dissolution of bone especially when associated with resorption
thrombocythaemia: a myeloproliferative disorder marked especially by an abnormal chronic increase in the number of circulating platelets
macrocytosis: the occurrence of macrocytes in the blood
amenorrhoea: abnormal absence or suppression of menstruation
s: sacral —used especially with a number from 1 to 5 to indicate a vertebra or segment of the spinal cord in the sacral region
albuminuria: the presence of albumin in the urine that is usually a symptom of disease of the kidneys but sometimes a response to other diseases or physiological disturbances of benign nature
osteochondrosis: a disease especially of children and young animals in which an ossification center especially in the epiphyses of long bones undergoes degeneration followed by calcification
lordosis: the normal convex curvature of the cervical and lumbar regions of the spine
hypomotility: abnormal deficiency of movement; specifically : decreased motility of all or part of the gastrointestinal tract
gene: a specific sequence of nucleotides in DNA or RNA that is located usually on a chromosome and that is the functional unit of inheritance controlling the transmission and expression of one or more traits by specifying the structure of a particular polypeptide and especially a protein or controlling the function of other genetic material called also determinant, determiner, factor
missed: an intrauterine death of a fetus that is not followed by its immediate expulsion
carbon: a nonmetallic element found native (as in diamonds and graphite) or as a constituent of coal, petroleum, asphalt, limestone, and organic compounds or obtained artificially (as in activated charcoal) —symbol C
dioxide: an oxide (as carbon dioxide) containing two atoms of oxygen in a molecule
anorgasmia: sexual dysfunction characterized by failure to achieve orgasm
lactation: the secretion and yielding of milk by the mammary gland
reading: any of the three possible ways of reading a sequence of nucleotides as a series of triplets
differentiation: the act of describing a thing by giving its differentia
sensorimotor: of, relating to, or functioning in both sensory and motor aspects of bodily activity
menopause: the natural cessation of menstruation occurring usually between the ages of 45 and 55
hypoparathyroidism: an endocrine disorder that is marked by a deficiency of parathyroid hormone resulting in hypocalcemia and hyperphosphatemia and that is characterized especially by muscle weakness and cramps, tingling or numbness of the lips, hands, or feet, fatigue, and sometimes tetany
habit: bodily appearance or makeup especially as indicative of one's capacities and condition
insulin: a protein hormone that is synthesized in the pancreas from proinsulin and secreted by the beta cells of the islets of Langerhans, that is essential for the metabolism of carbohydrates, lipids, and proteins, that regulates blood sugar levels by facilitating the uptake of glucose into tissues, by promoting its conversion into glycogen, fatty acids, and triglycerides, and by reducing the release of glucose from the liver, and that when produced in insufficient quantities results in diabetes mellitus
shipping: an often fatal febrile disease especially of young cattle and sheep that occurs under highly stressful conditions (as shipment over long distances and crowding in feedlots), is marked by high fever and pneumonia, and is caused by bacteria (especially Mannheimia haemolytica synonym Pasteurella haemolytica) usually in association with a virus
pubis: the ventral and anterior of the three principal bones composing either half of the pelvis that in humans consists of two rami diverging posteriorly from the region of the pubic symphysis with the superior ramus extending to the acetabulum of which it forms a part and uniting there with the ilium and ischium and the inferior ramus extending below the obturator foramen where it unites with the ischium called also pubic bone
norovirus: a genus of small, round, single-stranded, highly infectious RNA viruses that includes a single species (species Norwalk virus) with various strains causing gastroenteritis in people and animals (such as cows and dogs)
tympanic: of, relating to, or being a tympanum
connective: a tissue of mesodermal origin that consists of various cells (as fibroblasts and macrophages) and interlacing protein fibers (as of collagen) embedded in a chiefly carbohydrate ground substance, that supports, ensheathes, and binds together other tissues, and that includes loose and dense forms (as adipose tissue, tendons, ligaments, and aponeuroses) and specialized forms (as cartilage and bone)
monoxide: an oxide containing one atom of oxygen per molecule
macroglobulinaemia: a disorder characterized by increased blood serum viscosity and the presence of macroglobulins in the serum
agitated: a state of excessive psychomotor activity accompanied by increased tension and irritability
proteinosis: the accumulation of abnormal amounts of protein in bodily tissues
transfusion-related: a sometimes fatal complication of blood transfusion that is characterized by pulmonary edema not due to a cardiac condition, that may be accompanied by fever, dyspnea, hypoxemia, hypotension, or hypertension followed by hypotension, that usually starts one to two hours after blood is transfused and is usually resolved within 96 hours, and that is believed to be caused in susceptible individuals either by antibodies introduced into the blood pool by donors or by biologically active substances generated in stored blood abbreviation TRALI
first: emergency care or treatment given to an ill or injured person before regular medical aid can be obtained
degree: a measure of damage to tissue caused by injury or disease
maculopathy: any pathological condition of the macula of the eye
web: a tissue or membrane of an animal or plant; especially : that uniting fingers or toes either at their bases (as in humans) or for a greater part of their length (as in many waterbirds)
oticus: ramsay hunt syndrome; specifically : Ramsay Hunt syndrome when ear pain and rash are clinically present
beta: the second letter of the Greek alphabet symbol  or
mastitis: inflammation of the mammary gland or udder usually caused by infection called also mammitis
serratia: a genus of aerobic saprophytic flagellated rod-shaped bacteria of the family Enterobacteriaceae that occur as rods, commonly produce a bright red pigment, and include one (S. marcescens) associated with some human opportunistic infections
universalis: the complete and usually sudden loss of hair from the scalp, face, and body
staphylococcus: a genus of nonmotile gram-positive spherical bacteria that is placed in either of two families (Staphylococcaceae or Micrococcaceae), contains forms occurring singly, in pairs or tetrads, or in irregular clusters, and includes causative agents of various diseases and disorders (as food poisoning, skin infections, and endocarditis)
cerebrospinal: of or relating to the brain and spinal cord or to these together with the cranial and spinal nerves that innervate voluntary muscles
seronegative: having or being a negative serum reaction especially in a test for the presence of an antibody
ependymoma: a glioma arising in or near the ependyma
syphilis: a chronic contagious usually venereal and often congenital disease that is caused by a spirochete of the genus Treponema (T. pallidum) and if left untreated produces chancres, rashes, and systemic lesions in a clinical course with three stages continued over many years called also lues
lactose: a disaccharide sugar C12H22O11 that is present in milk, yields glucose and galactose upon hydrolysis, yields especially lactic acid upon fermentation, and is used chiefly in foods, medicines, and culture media (as for the manufacture of penicillin) called also milk sugar
burkholderia: a genus of bacteria (family Burkholderiaceae) formerly placed in the genus Pseudomonas and including the causative agents of glanders (B. mallei) and melioidosis (B. pseudomallei)
mucous: covered with or as if with mucus
distal: situated away from the point of attachment or origin or a central point: as
autoscopy: visual hallucination of an image of one's body
pre-existing: existing or present earlier or before a certain point of time
projectile: vomiting that is sudden, usually without nausea, and so vigorous that the vomit is forcefully projected to a distance
analgesic: relating to, characterized by, or producing analgesia
postictal: occurring after a sudden attack (as of epilepsy)
madarosis: loss of the eyelashes or of the hair of the eyebrows
curettage: a surgical scraping or cleaning by means of a curette
interrupted: a suture in which each stitch is separately tied
turnover: the continuous process of loss and replacement of a constituent (as a neurotransmitter, cell, or tissue) of a living system
covid-19: a mild to severe respiratory illness that is caused by a coronavirus (Severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 of the genus Betacoronavirus), is transmitted chiefly by contact with infectious material (such as respiratory droplets), and is characterized especially by fever, cough, loss of taste or smell, and shortness of breath and may progress to pneumonia and respiratory failure called also coronavirus, coronavirus disease, coronavirus disease 2019, CV-19, CV19
callus: a thickening of or a hard thickened area on skin
non-small: any carcinoma (as an adenocarcinoma or squamous cell carcinoma) of the lungs that is not a small-cell lung cancer called also non-small cell cancer, non-small cell carcinoma, non-small cell lung carcinoma
ii: a protein with vasoconstrictive activity that increases blood pressure, stimulates the release of aldosterone, is composed of a chain of eight amino acid residues, and is the physiologically active form of angiotensin
homicidal: of, relating to, or tending toward homicide
phimosis: tightness or constriction of the orifice of the foreskin arising either congenitally or postnatally (as from balanoposthitis) and preventing retraction of the foreskin over the glans
simple: free from complexity or difficulty: as
coronavirus: any of a family (Coronaviridae) of large, single-stranded, RNA viruses that have a lipid envelope studded with club-shaped spike proteins, infect birds and many mammals including humans, and include the causative agents of blue comb, feline infectious peritonitis, COVID-19, MERS, and SARS abbreviation CoV, CV
paralytic: affected with or characterized by paralysis
detoxification: to remove a poison or toxin or the effect of such from
orbital: a subdivision of a nuclear shell containing zero, one, or two electrons
anterior: relating to or situated near or toward the head or toward the part in headless animals most nearly corresponding to the head
chamber: an enclosed space within the body of an animal
generalisation: the action or process of becoming widespread or diffuse
cephalo-pelvic: a condition in which a maternal pelvis is small in relation to the size of the fetal head
disproportion: absence of symmetry or the proper dimensional relationship
regression: a trend or shift toward a lower, less severe, or less perfect state: as
intrauterine: of, situated in, used in, or occurring within the uterus; also : involving or occurring during the part of development that takes place in the uterus
contraceptive: a device or preparation (such as an IUD or birth control pill) that typically contains progestin either alone or in combination with estrogen and that prevents ovulation, thickens cervical mucus, or thins the uterine lining in order to prevent conception
trance: a sleeplike altered state of consciousness (as of deep hypnosis) usually characterized by partly suspended animation with diminished or absent sensory and motor activity and subsequent lack of recall
decompression: the act or process of releasing from pressure or compression: as
eastern: a venomous coral snake (Micrurus fulvius) of the southeastern U.S. having bright bands of black, red, and yellow
oncology: a branch of medicine concerned with the prevention, diagnosis, treatment, and study of cancer
group: a number of individuals assembled together or having some unifying relationship
testis: a typically paired male reproductive gland that usually consists largely of seminiferous tubules from the epithelium of which spermatozoa develop, that contains androgen-secreting Leydig cells in the interstitial tissue, that corresponds to the ovary of the female and in craniate vertebrates develops from the genital ridges of the embryo, and that in most mammals descends into the scrotum before the attainment of sexual maturity and in many cases before birth
wisdom: the third molar that is the last tooth to erupt on each side of the upper and lower human jaw
interference: the act or process of interfering
pneumovirus: any of a family (Pneumoviridae) of single-stranded RNA viruses that have a filamentous or spherical virion with a lipid-containing envelope, typically cause respiratory infections in mammals and birds, include the respiratory syncytial virus and metapneumovirus, and were formerly classified as paramyxoviruses
sars-cov-2: the coronavirus (Severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 of the genus Betacoronavirus) that is the causative agent of COVID-19
pitting: the action or process of forming pits (as in acned skin, a tooth, or a dental restoration)
haemophilus: a genus of nonmotile, gram-negative, rod-shaped bacteria of the family Pasteurellaceae that include several important pathogens (as H. influenzae associated with meningitis, pneumonia, conjunctivitis, and otitis media and H. ducreyi of chancroid)
triple: a chemical bond in which three pairs of electrons are shared by two atoms in a molecule and which is usually represented in chemical formulas by three lines
myelosuppression: suppression of the bone marrow's production of blood cells and platelets
mastocytosis: excessive proliferation of mast cells in the tissues; specifically : a rare variable disorder marked by the abnormal proliferation and accumulation of mast cells in the skin, bone marrow, or internal organs
subclavian: of, relating to, being, performed on, or inserted into a part (as an artery or vein) located under the clavicle
pyoderma: a bacterial skin inflammation marked by pus-filled lesions
transurethral: passing through or performed by way of the urethra
prostatectomy: surgical removal or resection of the prostate gland
anogenital: of, relating to, or involving the genital organs and the anus
warts: a horny projection on the skin usually of the extremities produced by proliferation of the skin papillae and caused by any of numerous genotypes of the human papillomavirus
pigment: a coloring matter in animals and plants especially in a cell or tissue; also : any of various related colorless substances
tear: a drop of clear saline fluid secreted by the lacrimal gland and diffused between the eye and eyelids to moisten the parts and facilitate their motion
an: a usually involuntary shutting and opening of the eye
immunocompromised: having the immune system impaired or weakened (as by drugs or illness)
manipulation: the act, process, or an instance of manipulating especially a body part by manual examination and treatment; especially : adjustment of faulty structural relationships by manual means (as in the reduction of fractures or dislocations or the breaking down of adhesions)
ultrasound: vibrations of the same physical nature as sound but with frequencies above the range of human hearing
scan: to examine especially systematically with a sensing device (as a photometer or a beam of radiation)
enterostomy: a surgical formation of an opening into the intestine through the abdominal wall
out: relating to or involving a feeling of separation from one's body and of being able to view oneself and others from an external perspective
flank: the fleshy part of the side between the ribs and the hip; broadly : the side of a quadruped
laser: a device that utilizes the natural oscillations of atoms or molecules between energy levels for generating coherent electromagnetic radiation usually in the ultraviolet, visible, or infrared regions of the spectrum
menopausal: the natural cessation of menstruation occurring usually between the ages of 45 and 55
lentigo: a small melanotic spot in the skin in which the formation of pigment is unrelated to exposure to sunlight and which is potentially malignant; especially : nevus
carcinoid: a benign or malignant tumor arising especially from the mucosa of the gastrointestinal tract (as in the stomach or appendix)
hypervolaemia: an excessive volume of blood in the body
thrombocytosis: increase and especially abnormal increase in the number of platelets in the blood that typically occurs in association with a myeloproliferative disorder (as thrombocythemia or chronic myelogenous leukemia) or as a nonspecific response to an underlying disorder or disease (as a systemic infection); also : thrombocythemia
patch: a piece of material used medically usually to cover a wound or repair a defect
measles: an acute contagious disease that is caused by a paramyxovirus of the genus Morbillivirus (species Measles morbillivirus), that commences with catarrhal symptoms, conjunctivitis, cough, and Koplik's spots on the oral mucous membrane, and that is marked by the appearance on the third or fourth day of an eruption of distinct red circular spots which coalesce in a crescentic form, are slightly raised, and after the fourth day of the eruption gradually decline called also rubeola
restenosis: the reoccurrence of stenosis in a blood vessel or heart valve after it has been treated (as by balloon angioplasty or valvuloplasty) with apparent success
miller: a double-lumen balloon-tipped rubber tube used for the purpose of decompression in treating intestinal obstruction
histoplasmosis: a respiratory disease with symptoms like those of influenza that is endemic in the Mississippi and Ohio river valleys of the United States, is caused by infection with a fungus of the genus Histoplasma (H. capsulatum), and is marked by benign involvement of lymph nodes of the trachea and bronchi usually without symptoms or by severe progressive generalized involvement of the lymph nodes and macrophage-rich tissues (as of the liver and spleen) with fever, anemia, leukopenia and often with local lesions (as of the skin, mouth, or throat)
chalazion: a small circumscribed tumor of the eyelid formed by retention of secretions of the meibomian gland and sometimes accompanied by inflammation
aplastic: not exhibiting growth or change in structure
osmolar: the concentration of an osmotic solution especially when measured in osmols or milliosmols per liter of solution
folate: folic acid; also : a salt or ester of folic acid
dyslipidaemia: a condition marked by abnormal concentrations of lipids or lipoproteins in the blood
extramedullary: situated or occurring outside the spinal cord or the medulla oblongata
hypermetabolism: metabolism at an increased or excessive rate
hypertriglyceridaemia: the presence of an excess of triglycerides in the blood
coloboma: a fissure of the eye usually of congenital origin
giant: an unusually large cell; especially : a large multinucleate often phagocytic cell (as those characteristic of tubercular lesions, various sarcomas, or the megakaryocytes of the red marrow)
prolactin: a protein hormone of the adenohypophysis of the pituitary gland that induces and maintains lactation in the postpartum mammalian female abbreviation PRLcalled also luteotropic hormone, luteotropin, mammotropin
amphetamines: a racemic sympathomimetic amine C9H13N or one of its derivatives (as dextroamphetamine or methamphetamine) that is a stimulant of the central nervous system, is frequently abused illicitly often leading to dependence, and is used clinically especially in the form of its sulfate C9H13NH2SO4 to treat attention deficit disorder and narcolepsy and formerly as a short-term appetite suppressant
bed: a piece of furniture on or in which one may lie and sleep
infantile: of, relating to, or occurring in infants or infancy
dextrocardia: an abnormal condition in which the heart is situated on the right side and the great blood vessels of the right and left sides are reversed
hypoplasia: a condition of arrested development in which an organ or part remains below the normal size or in an immature state
hygroma: a cystic tumor of lymphatic origin
transposition: an act, process, or instance of transposing or being transposed: as
vessels: a tube or canal (as an artery, vein, or lymphatic) in which a body fluid (as blood or lymph) is contained and conveyed or circulated
induced: to cause or bring about : as
floor: the lower inside surface of a hollow anatomical structure
binge: an act of excessive or compulsive consumption especially of food or alcoholic beverages
transcatheter: performed through the lumen of a catheter
lichen: any of several skin diseases characterized by the eruption of flat papules; especially : lichen planus
clitoris: a female erogenous organ that consists of an externally visible, highly innervated small conical structure or glans that lies at the anterior junction of the labia minora above the urethral opening and is continuous internally with a short body of paired cylinders of vascular, erectile corpus cavernosum tissue which branch into curved extensions or crura attaching to the pubic arch and with two elongated masses of erectile tissue (the bulb of the vestibule) situated near each side of the vaginal and urethral openings
polymerase: any of several enzymes that catalyze the formation of DNA or RNA from precursor substances in the presence of preexisting DNA or RNA acting as a template
chain: a series of things (as bacteria) linked, connected, or associated together
glucose-6-phosphate: an ester C6H13O9P that is formed from glucose and ATP in the presence of a glucokinase and that is an essential early stage in glucose metabolism
papilloedema: swelling and protrusion of the blind spot of the eye caused by edema called also choked disk
adrenocorticotropic: acting on or stimulating the adrenal cortex
ketosis: an abnormal increase of ketone bodies in the body in conditions of reduced or disturbed carbohydrate metabolism (as in uncontrolled diabetes mellitus)
interventional: the act or fact or a means of interfering with the outcome or course especially of a condition or process (as to prevent harm or improve functioning)
depth: the distance between upper and lower or between dorsal and ventral points of a body
perception: awareness of the elements of environment through physical sensation
products: a substance produced from one or more other substances as a result of chemical change
conception: the process of becoming pregnant involving fertilization or implantation or both
anastomosis: a communication between or coalescence of blood vessels
amoebiasis: infection with or disease caused by amoebas (especially Entamoeba histolytica)
dysfunctional: impaired or abnormal functioning (as of an organ of the body)
activation: to make active or more active: as
excursion: a movement outward and back or from a mean position or axis
hyposmia: impairment of the sense of smell
disorganised: psychopathological inconsistency in personality, mental functions, or overt behavior
azotaemia: an excess of urea and other nitrogenous wastes in the blood as a result of kidney insufficiency
periodic: occurring or recurring at regular intervals
frontotemporal: of or relating to the frontal and the temporal bones
compulsive: of, relating to, caused by, or suggestive of psychological compulsion or obsession
masturbation: erotic stimulation especially of one's own genital organs commonly resulting in orgasm and achieved by manual or other bodily contact exclusive of sexual intercourse, by instrumental manipulation, occasionally by sexual fantasies, or by various combinations of these agencies
myelogram: a differential study of the cellular elements present in bone marrow usually made on material obtained by sternal biopsy
osteitis: inflammation of bone called also ostitis
daydreaming: a visionary creation of the imagination experienced while awake; especially : a gratifying reverie usually of wish fulfillment
penoscrotal: of or relating to the penis and scrotum
carcinoembryonic: a glycoprotein present in fetal gut tissues during the first two trimesters of pregnancy and in peripheral blood of patients with some forms of cancer (as of the digestive system or the breast) abbreviation CEA
globulins: any of a class of simple proteins (as myosin) that are insoluble in pure water but are soluble in dilute salt solutions and that occur widely in plant and animal tissues
fibrinogen: a plasma protein that is produced in the liver and is converted into fibrin during blood clot formation
fibrin: a white insoluble fibrous protein formed from fibrinogen by the action of thrombin especially in the clotting of blood
dimer: a compound formed by the union of two radicals or two molecules of a simpler compound; specifically : a polymer formed from two molecules of a monomer
bearing: an object, surface, or point that supports
alkalosis: an abnormal condition of increased alkalinity of the blood and tissues
proctitis: inflammation of the anus and rectum
5-alpha-reductase: an enzyme that catalyzes the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone
solubility: the quality or state of being soluble
gastrostomy: the surgical formation of an opening through the abdominal wall into the stomach
hepatopathy: an abnormal or diseased state of the liver
glycolysis: the enzymatic breakdown of a carbohydrate (as glucose or glycogen) by way of phosphate derivatives with the production of pyruvic or lactic acid and energy stored in high-energy phosphate bonds of ATP called also Embden-Meyerhof pathway
hydroxybutyrate: a salt or ester of hydroxybutyric acid
precursor: one that precedes and indicates the onset of another
apraxia: loss or impairment of the ability to execute complex coordinated movements without muscular or sensory impairment
sciatic: of, relating to, or situated near the hip
erysipeloid: an acute dermatitis resembling erysipelas that is caused by the bacterium of the genus Erysipelothrix (E. rhusiopathiae) that causes swine erysipelas, is typically marked by usually painful reddish purple lesions especially on the hands, and that is contracted by direct contact with infected animal flesh
ketone: an organic compound (as acetone) with a carbonyl group attached to two carbon atoms
immediate: acting or being without the intervention of another object, cause, or agency : being direct
post-injection: occurring or existing in the period following injection
mutism: the condition of being unable to speak whether from physical, functional, or psychological cause
hyperinsulinaemic: the presence of excess insulin in the blood
myelofibrosis: an anemic condition in which bone marrow becomes fibrotic and the liver and spleen usually exhibit a development of blood-cell precursors
reticulin: a protein substance similar to collagen that is a constituent of reticular tissue
concentration: the act or action of concentrating: as
cubital: of or relating to a cubitus
paraplegia: partial or complete paralysis of the lower half of the body with involvement of both legs that is usually due to injury or disease of the spinal cord in the thoracic or lumbar region
thyroidectomy: surgical excision of thyroid gland tissue
anosognosia: an inability or refusal to recognize a defect or disorder that is clinically evident
weber: the practical mks unit of magnetic flux equal to that flux which in linking a circuit of one turn produces in it an electromotive force of one volt as the flux is reduced to zero at a uniform rate in one second : 108 maxwells
tuning: a 2-pronged metal implement that gives a fixed tone when struck
fork: a forked part, tool, or piece of equipment
stem: an unspecialized cell capable of perpetuating itself through cell division and having the potential to give rise to differentiated cells with specialized functions
lymphocytic: any of the colorless weakly motile cells that originate from stem cells and differentiate in lymphoid tissue (as of the thymus or bone marrow), that are the typical cellular elements of lymph, that include the cellular mediators of immunity, and that constitute 20 to 30 percent of the white blood cells of normal human blood
intra-ocular: implanted in, occurring within, or administered by entering the eyeball
hostility: conflict, opposition, or resistance in thought or principle
design: a plan or protocol for carrying out or accomplishing something (especially a scientific experiment); also : the process of preparing this
crystalluria: the presence of crystals in the urine indicating renal irritation (as that caused by sulfa drugs)
peau: thickened, dimpled skin that resembles the rind of an orange and is often associated with some forms of breast cancer
sternal: of or relating to the sternum
fragility: the quality or state of being easily broken or destroyed
psoriasiform: resembling psoriasis or a psoriatic lesion
otorrhoea: a discharge from the external ear
adenomyosis: endometriosis especially when the endometrial tissue invades the myometrium
leiden: a point mutation producing an abnormal version of factor V that is resistant to inactivation and causes prolonged clotting of blood
contracture: a permanent shortening (as of muscle, tendon, or scar tissue) producing deformity or distortion
spondyloarthropathy: any of several diseases (as ankylosing spondylitis) affecting the joints of the spine
restoration: the act of restoring or the condition of being restored: as
urogenital: of, relating to, affecting, treating, or being the organs or functions of excretion and reproduction : genitourinary
penis: the male erectile copulatory organ of a higher vertebrate animal developing from the genital tubercle that in mammals including humans usually functions as the channel by which urine and semen are discharged from the body and is typically a cylindrical organ that is suspended from the pubic arch, contains a pair of large lateral corpora cavernosa and a smaller ventromedial corpus cavernosum containing the urethra, and has a terminal glans enclosing the ends of the corpora cavernosa, covered by mucous membrane, and sheathed by a foreskin continuous with the skin covering the body of the organ
fibromatosis: a condition marked by the presence of or a tendency to develop multiple fibromas
order: to give a prescription for : prescribe
anticoagulation: the process of hindering the clotting of blood; especially : the use of an anticoagulant to prevent the formation of blood clots
bursal: a bodily pouch or sac: as
tetany: a condition of physiological calcium imbalance that is marked by intermittent tonic spasm of the voluntary muscles and is associated with deficiencies of parathyroid secretion or other disturbances (as vitamin D deficiency)
hepatectomy: excision of the liver or of part of the liver
tracheo-oesophageal: relating to or connecting the trachea and the esophagus
phlebotomy: the letting of blood (as by venipuncture) for transfusion, apheresis, diagnostic testing, or experimental procedures and widely used in the past to treat many types of disease but now limited to the treatment of only a few specific conditions (as hemochromatosis and polycythemia vera) called also venesection, venotomy
artificial: humanly contrived often on a natural model
crown: the topmost part of the skull or head
kleptomania: a persistent neurotic impulse to steal especially without economic motive
rotation: the action or process of rotating on or as if on an axis or center; specifically : the turning of a body part about its long axis as if on a pivot
drowning: to suffocate in water or some other liquid
hyporesponsive: characterized by a diminished degree of responsiveness (as to a physical or emotional stimulus)
brugada: an inherited life-threatening cardiac disorder of abnormal heart rhythm that may be marked by episodes of fainting or that may be asymptomatic until ventricular tachycardia results in ventricular fibrillation leading to cardiac arrest or sudden cardiac death
active: capable of acting or reacting especially in some specific way
malabsorption: faulty absorption of nutrient materials from the digestive tract called also malassimilation
meibomian: one of the long sebaceous glands of the eyelids that discharge a fatty secretion which lubricates the eyelids called also tarsal gland
pancreas: a large lobulated gland that in humans lies in front of the upper lumbar vertebrae and behind the stomach and is somewhat hammer-shaped and firmly attached anteriorly to the curve of the duodenum with which it communicates through one or more pancreatic ducts and that consists of (1) tubular acini secreting digestive enzymes which pass to the intestine and function in the breakdown of proteins, fats, and carbohydrates; (2) modified acinar cells that form islets of Langerhans between the tubules and secrete the hormones insulin and glucagon; and (3) a firm connective-tissue capsule that extends supportive strands into the organ
avoidant: characterized by turning away or by withdrawal or defensive behavior
phosphorus: a nonmetallic multivalent element that occurs widely in combined form especially as inorganic phosphates in minerals, soils, natural waters, bones, and teeth and as organic phosphates in all living cells and that exists in several allotropic forms —symbol P
yawning: to open the mouth wide and take a deep breath usually as an involuntary reaction to fatigue or boredom
smear: material spread on a surface (as of a microscopic slide); also : a preparation made by spreading material on a surface
environment: the complex of physical, chemical, and biotic factors (as climate, soil, and living things) that act upon an organism or an ecological community and ultimately determine its form and survival
null-cell: a lymphocyte in the blood that does not have on its surface the receptors typical of either mature B cells or T cells
types: a lower taxonomic category selected as a standard of reference for a higher category; also : a specimen or series of specimens on which a taxonomic species or subspecies is actually based
hyperarousal: excessive arousal : an abnormal state of increased responsiveness to stimuli that is marked by various physiological and psychological symptoms (as increased levels of alertness and anxiety and elevated heart rate and respiration)
reactive: of, relating to, or marked by reaction
borrelia: a genus of small flexible spirochetes of the family Spirochaetaceae that are parasites of humans and warm-blooded animals and include the causative agents of septicemia in chickens (B. recurrentis), relapsing fever in Africa (B. duttoni), and Lyme disease in the United States (B. burgdorferi)
hyperamylasaemia: the presence of an excess of amylase in the blood serum
vasoconstriction: narrowing of the lumen of blood vessels especially as a result of vasomotor action
ulna: the bone on the little-finger side of the human forearm that forms with the humerus the elbow joint and serves as a pivot in rotation of the hand
erythroblast: a polychromatic nucleated cell of red marrow that synthesizes hemoglobin and that is an intermediate in the initial stage of red blood cell formation; broadly : a cell ancestral to red blood cells
waist: the typically narrowed part of the body between the thorax and hips
relapsing: to slip or fall back into a former worse state (as of illness) after a change for the better
bacillus: a genus of rod-shaped gram-positive endospore-producing usually aerobic bacteria of the family Bacillaceae that include many saprophytes and some parasites (as B. anthracis of anthrax)
obstetric: of, relating to, or associated with childbirth or obstetrics
minimal: relating to or being a minimum : constituting the least possible with respect to size, number, degree, or certain stated conditions
fire: fever or inflammation especially from a disease
onychomycosis: a fungal disease of the nails
glioblastoma: a malignant rapidly growing astrocytoma of the central nervous system and usually of a cerebral hemisphere called also glioblastoma multiforme
iris: the opaque muscular contractile diaphragm that is suspended in the aqueous humor in front of the lens of the eye, is perforated by the pupil and is continuous peripherally with the ciliary body, has a deeply pigmented posterior surface which excludes the entrance of light except through the pupil and a colored anterior surface which determines the color of the eyes
neovascularisation: vascularization especially in abnormal quantity (as in some conditions of the retina) or in abnormal tissue (as a tumor)
alarm: the initial reaction of an organism (as increased hormonal activity) to stress
caecum: a cavity open at one end (as the blind end of a duct); especially : the blind pouch at the beginning of the large intestine into which the ileum opens from one side and which is continuous with the colon
dissociative: of, relating to, or tending to produce dissociation
identity: the distinguishing character or personality of an individual
distractibility: a condition in which the attention of the mind is easily distracted by small and irrelevant stimuli
quarantine: a term during which a ship arriving in port and suspected of carrying contagious disease is held in isolation from the shore
dysentery: a disease characterized by severe diarrhea with passage of mucus and blood and usually caused by infection
genitourinary: of, relating to, affecting, or being the organs of reproduction and urination : urogenital
isolation: the action of isolating or condition of being isolated
bloody: containing or made up of blood
perinatal: occurring in, concerned with, or being in the period around the time of birth
prurigo: a chronic inflammatory skin disease marked by a general eruption of small itching papules
anti-thyroid: able to counteract excessive thyroid activity
measured: to allot or apportion in measured amounts
potency: the quality or state of being potent: as
delusional: relating to, based on, or affected by delusions
jugular: of or relating to the throat or neck
retinoschisis: degenerative splitting of the retina into separate layers
inhibition: the act or an instance of inhibiting or the state of being inhibited: as
gastroduodenal: of, relating to, or involving both the stomach and the duodenum
oestrogen: any of various natural steroids (as estradiol) that are formed from androgen precursors, that are secreted chiefly by the ovaries, placenta, adipose tissue, and testes, and that stimulate the development of female secondary sex characteristics and promote the growth and maintenance of the female reproductive system; also : any of various synthetic or semisynthetic steroids (as ethinyl estradiol) that mimic the physiological effect of natural estrogens
oestradiol: a natural estrogenic hormone that is a phenolic alcohol C18H24O2 secreted chiefly by the ovaries, is the most potent of the naturally occurring estrogens, and is administered in its natural or semisynthetic esterified form especially to treat menopausal symptoms called also dihydrotheelin
dermatomyositis: polymyositis that is accompanied by involvement of the skin and that is typically marked by reddish erythematous eruptions especially on the face, neck, upper trunk and distal half of the limbs, by periorbital edema, by violet-colored erythema of the eyelids and region over the upper eyelids, and sometimes by cutaneous vasculitis or subcutaneous calcification abbreviation DM
myelogenous: of, relating to, originating in, or produced by the bone marrow
enzymes: any of numerous complex proteins that are produced by living cells and catalyze specific biochemical reactions at body temperatures
grunting: abnormal respiration in a horse marked by a laryngeal sound emitted when it is struck or moved suddenly
hydrothorax: an excess of serous fluid in the pleural cavity; especially : an effusion resulting from failing circulation (as in heart disease or from lung infection)
parapsoriasis: a rare skin disease characterized by red scaly patches similar to those of psoriasis but causing no sensations of pain or itch
embolisation: the process by which or state in which a blood vessel or organ is obstructed by the lodgment of a material mass (as an embolus)
seborrhoea: abnormally increased secretion and discharge of sebum producing an oily appearance of the skin and the formation of greasy scales
examination: the act or process of inspecting or testing for evidence of disease or abnormality
hyposecretion: production of a bodily secretion at an abnormally slow rate or in abnormally small quantities
immunisation: the creation of immunity usually against a particular disease; especially : treatment (as by vaccination) of an organism for the purpose of making it immune to a particular pathogen
sick: affected with disease or ill health
building: a clinically diagnosable disease or condition (as Legionnaires' disease or an allergic reaction) caused by a microorganism or substance demonstrably present in a building abbreviation BRI
mucosa: a membrane rich in mucous glands that lines body passages and cavities (as of the digestive, respiratory, and genitourinary tracts) which connect directly or indirectly with the exterior : mucous membrane
illusion: a misleading image presented as a visual stimulus
air: a mixture of invisible odorless tasteless sound-transmitting gases that is composed by volume chiefly of 78 percent nitrogen, 21 percent oxygen, 0.9 percent argon, 0.03 percent carbon dioxide, varying amounts of water vapor, and minute amounts of rare gases (as helium), that surrounds the earth with half its mass within four miles of the earth's surface, that has a pressure at sea level of about 14.7 pounds per square inch, and that has a density of 1.293 grams per liter at 0°C and 760 mm pressure
absorption: the process of absorbing or of being absorbed
menometrorrhagia: a combination of menorrhagia and metrorrhagia
hypochloraemia: abnormal decrease of chlorides in the blood
erythropoietin: a hormonal substance that is formed especially in the kidney and stimulates red blood cell formation abbreviation EPO
implant: to set permanently in the consciousness or habit patterns
keloid: a thick scar resulting from excessive growth of fibrous tissue and occurring especially after burns or radiation injury
receptor: a cell or group of cells that receives stimuli : sense organ
appendix: a bodily outgrowth or process; specifically : vermiform appendix
papillary: of, relating to, or resembling a papilla : papillose
anti-platelet: acting against or destroying blood platelets
continuous: marked by uninterrupted extension in space, time, or sequence : continuing without intermission or recurring regularly after minute interruptions
cheek: the fleshy side of the face below the eye and above and to the side of the mouth; broadly : the lateral aspect of the head
spider: any of an order (Araneae synonym Araneida) of arachnids having a body with two main divisions, four pairs of walking legs, and two or more pairs of abdominal spinnerets for spinning threads of silk used especially in making webs for catching prey
choroidal: a vascular membrane containing large branched pigment cells that lies between the retina and the sclera of the eye called also choroid coat
ventilation: the circulation and exchange of gases in the lungs or gills that is basic to respiration
suppression: an act or instance of suppressing: as
plants: a tropical Old World herb of the genus Ricinus (R. communis) widely grown as an ornamental or for its oil-rich castor beans that are a source of castor oil
meningoencephalitis: inflammation of the brain and meninges called also encephalomeningitis
anticholinergic: opposing or blocking the physiological action of acetylcholine
hypophosphataemic: deficiency of phosphates in the blood that is due to inadequate intake, excessive excretion, or defective absorption and that results in various abnormalities (as defects of bone)
osteomalacia: a disease of adults that is characterized by softening of the bones and is analogous to rickets in the young
burns: to produce or undergo discomfort or pain
acetabulum: the cup-shaped socket in the hip bone
intrahepatic: situated or occurring within or originating in the liver
nasopharyngeal: of, relating to, or affecting the nose and pharynx or the nasopharynx
carcinogenicity: producing or tending to produce cancer
livedo: a bluish usually patchy discoloration of the skin
defects: a lack or deficiency of something necessary for adequacy in form or function
stromal: the supporting framework of an animal organ typically consisting of connective tissue
macroglossia: pathological and commonly congenital enlargement of the tongue
hypnagogic: of, relating to, or occurring in the period of drowsiness immediately preceding sleep
recovery: the act of regaining or returning toward a normal or healthy state
anaesthesia: loss of sensation with or without loss of consciousness that is artificially produced by the administration of one or more agents that block the passage of pain impulses along nerve pathways to the brain
blinking: to close and open the eyes involuntarily (as when struggling against drowsiness or when dazzled)
light: the sensation aroused by stimulation of the visual receptors
hormones: a product of living cells that circulates in body fluids (as blood) or sap and produces a specific often stimulatory effect on the activity of cells usually a distance from its point of synthesis
haematopoietic: of, relating to, or involved in the formation of blood cells
ingestion: the taking of material (as food) into the digestive system
foaming: a light frothy mass of fine bubbles formed in or on the surface of a liquid
nephrostomy: the surgical formation of an opening between a renal pelvis and the outside of the body
colloid: a gelatinous or mucinous substance found in tissues in disease or normally (as in the thyroid)
pachygyria: mild to moderate lissencephaly marked by a cerebral cortex with only a few broad, flat convolutions : incomplete lissencephaly
giardiasis: infestation with or disease caused by a flagellate protozoan of the genus Giardia (especially G. lamblia) that is often characterized by diarrhea called also lambliasis
communicable: capable of being transmitted from person to person, animal to animal, animal to human, or human to animal : transmissible
cardiopulmonary: of or relating to the heart and lungs
epithelium: a membranous cellular tissue that covers a free surface or lines a tube or cavity of an animal body and serves especially to enclose and protect the other parts of the body, to produce secretions and excretions, and to function in assimilation
xiii: a clotting factor that is catalyzed by thrombin during the final stage of clot formation to an active form which cross-links strands of fibrin resulting in a stable, insoluble clot called also fibrinase
agent: something that produces or is capable of producing an effect
chloride: a compound of chlorine with another element or radical; especially : a salt or ester of hydrochloric acid —called also muriate
transcription: the process of constructing a messenger RNA molecule using a DNA molecule as a template with resulting transfer of genetic information to the messenger RNA
feelings: the capacity or ability to experience physical sensations (such as pain, touch, or temperature) that is mediated chiefly by end organs and sensory receptors in the skin
arnold-chiari: a congenital abnormality in which the lower surface of the cerebellum and the lower brain stem protrude into the spinal canal through the foramen magnum
monocytosis: an abnormal increase in the number of monocytes in the circulating blood
tryptase: a protease of human mast cells that has been implicated as a pathological mediator of numerous allergic and inflammatory conditions (as asthma, rhinitis, and conjunctivitis)
fibronectin: any of a group of glycoproteins of cell surfaces, blood plasma, and connective tissue that promote cellular adhesion and migration
unconsciousness: not marked by conscious thought, sensation, or feeling
polycythaemia: a condition marked by an abnormal increase in the number of circulating red blood cells; especially : polycythemia vera
cholangiocarcinoma: a usually slow-growing malignant tumor of the bile duct that arises from biliary epithelium and is typically an adenocarcinoma
proliferative: capable of or engaged in proliferation
disorder,: to disturb the regular or normal functions of
microbial: of, relating to, caused by, or being microbes
laxity: the quality or state of being loose
relaxation: the act of relaxing or state of being relaxed
pelvis: a basin-shaped structure in the skeleton of many vertebrates that is formed by the pelvic girdle and adjoining bones of the spine and that in humans is bounded laterally by the two hip bones, anteriorly by the pubis, and posteriorly by the sacrum and coccyx
amino: relating to, being, or containing an amine group often used in combination
uterus: an organ in female mammals for containing and usually for nourishing the young during development prior to birth that consists of a greatly modified and enlarged section of an oviduct (as in rodents and marsupials) or of the two oviducts united (as in the higher primates including humans), that has thick walls consisting of an outer serous layer, a very thick middle layer of smooth muscle, and an inner mucous layer containing numerous glands, and that during pregnancy undergoes great increase in size and change in the condition of its walls called also womb
stomal: of, relating to, or situated near a surgical stoma
placental: of, relating to, having, involving, or produced by a placenta
bezoar: any of various calculi found in the gastrointestinal organs especially of ruminants called also bezoar stone
laparoscopy: visual examination of the inside of the abdomen by means of a laparoscope called also peritoneoscopy
spitting: to eject (as saliva) from the mouth
premenstrual: of, relating to, occurring in, or being in the period just preceding menstruation
constrictive: to make narrow or draw together
electric: of, relating to, or operated by electricity
pulpitis: inflammation of the pulp of a tooth
age-related: macular degeneration that affects the elderly in either a slowly progressing form marked especially by the accumulation of yellow deposits in and thinning of the macula or in a rapidly progressing form marked by scarring produced by bleeding and fluid leakage below the macula abbreviation AMD
narcolepsy: a condition characterized by brief attacks of deep sleep often occurring with cataplexy and hypnagogic hallucinations
donor: one used as a source of biological material (as blood or an organ)
transmission: an act, process, or instance of transmitting
feminisation: to cause (a male or castrate) to take on feminine characters (as by implantation of ovaries or administration of estrogenic substances)
pupillary: of or relating to the pupil of the eye
morbid: of, relating to, or characteristic of disease
keratopathy: any noninflammatory disease of the eye
ultrafiltration: filtration through a medium (as a semipermeable capillary wall) which allows small molecules (as of water) to pass but holds back larger ones (as of protein)
cytolysis: the usually pathological dissolution or disintegration of cells
amniocentesis: the surgical insertion of a hollow needle through the abdominal wall and into the uterus of a pregnant female to obtain amniotic fluid especially to examine the fetal chromosomes for an abnormality and for the determination of sex
augmentation: the act, action, or process of augmenting
clonic: exhibiting, relating to, or involving clonus
cellulite: deposits of subcutaneous fat within fibrous connective tissue (as in the thighs, hips, and buttocks) that give a puckered and dimpled appearance to the skin surface
haemosiderin: a yellowish brown granular pigment formed by breakdown of hemoglobin, found in phagocytes and in tissues especially in disturbances of iron metabolism (as in hemochromatosis, hemosiderosis, or some anemias), and composed essentially of colloidal ferric oxide
lipodystrophy: a disorder of fat metabolism especially involving loss of fat from or deposition of fat in tissue
allogenic: involving, derived from, or being individuals of the same species that are sufficiently unlike genetically to interact antigenically
lymphoid: of, relating to, or being tissue (as the lymph nodes or thymus) containing lymphocytes
philadelphia: an abnormally short chromosome 22 that is found in the hematopoietic cells of persons affected with chronic myelogenous leukemia and lacks the major part of its long arm which has usually undergone translocation to chromosome 9
chromosome: any of the rod-shaped or threadlike DNA-containing structures of cellular organisms that are located in the nucleus of eukaryotes, are usually ring-shaped in prokaryotes (as bacteria), and contain all or most of the genes of the organism; also : the genetic material of a virus
porphyria: any of several usually hereditary abnormalities of porphyrin metabolism characterized by excretion of excess porphyrins in the urine and by extreme sensitivity to light
agonal: of, relating to, or associated with the act of dying : occurring just before death
bicuspid: having or ending in two points
aorta: the large arterial trunk that carries blood from the heart to be distributed by branch arteries through the body
reduction: the replacement or realignment of a body part in normal position or restoration of a bodily condition to normal
nutrition: the act or process of nourishing or being nourished; specifically : the sum of the processes by which an animal or plant takes in and utilizes food substances
pleuritic: of, relating to, or affected with pleurisy
relationship: the state of being related or interrelated
end-diastolic: relating to or occurring in the moment immediately preceding contraction of the heart
prostatism: disease of the prostate gland; especially : a disorder resulting from obstruction of the bladder neck by an enlarged prostate gland
ureteric: of or relating to a ureter
neurostimulator: a device that provides electrical stimulation to nerves (as to relieve intractable pain or to suppress tremors)
sexually: of, relating to, or associated with sex or the sexes
transmitted: to pass, transfer, or convey from one person or place to another: as
spastic: of, relating to, or characterized by spasm
coombs: an agglutination test used to detect proteins and especially antibodies on the surface of red blood cells
hypochloraemic: of, relating to, or characterized by hypochloremia
junctional: a place or point of meeting
intraventricular: situated within, occurring within, or administered into a ventricle
antidepressant: used or tending to relieve or prevent psychological depression : relating to, being, or utilizing an antidepressant
otorhinolaryngological: a medical specialty concerned especially with the ear, nose, and throat and related parts of the head and neck : otolaryngology
thrombin: a proteolytic enzyme formed from prothrombin that facilitates the clotting of blood by catalyzing conversion of fibrinogen to fibrin and that is used in the form of a powder as a topical hemostatic called also thrombase
supine: lying on the back or with the face upward
halo: a circle of light appearing to surround a luminous body; especially : one seen as the result of the presence of glaucoma
vancomycin: an antibiotic C66H75Cl2N9O24 derived from an actinomycete (Amycolatopsis orientalis synonym Streptomyces orientalis synonym Nocardia orientalis) that is effective against gram-positive bacteria and is used chiefly in the form of its hydrochloride C66H75Cl2N9O24·HCl especially against staphylococci resistant to methicillin
ablation: the process of ablating; especially : surgical removal
urethra: the canal that in most mammals carries off the urine from the bladder and in the male serves also as a passageway for semen
ganglioneuroma: a neuroma derived from ganglion cells
hyperostosis: excessive growth or thickening of bone tissue
subretinal: situated or occurring beneath the retina
phase: a particular appearance or state in a regularly recurring cycle of changes
gonorrhoea: a contagious inflammation of the genital mucous membrane caused by the gonococcus called also clap
demineralisation: loss of minerals (as salts of calcium) from the body especially in disease
following: to maintain contact with (a patient) at one or more designated intervals following diagnosis or treatment especially to examine again or monitor the progress of therapy
natriuretic: excessive loss of cations and especially sodium in the urine
granulocyte: any of a group of white blood cells (as a basophil, eosinophil, or neutrophil) characterized by granule-containing cytoplasm and a usually lobed nucleus
cd8: a glycoprotein that is found associated with a T cell receptor especially on the surface of a cytotoxic T cell and that binds to a major histocompatibility complex molecule on the surface of an antigen-presenting cell to facilitate antigen recognition and cytotoxic T cell activation often used before another noun
intraductal: situated within, occurring within, or introduced into a duct
granulation: the act or process of granulating : the condition of being granulated
pneumatocele: a gas-filled cavity or sac occurring especially in the lung
immobilisation: the act of immobilizing or state of being immobilized: as
positional: a particular arrangement or location; specifically : an arrangement of the parts of the body considered particularly desirable for some medical or surgical procedure
hand-foot-and-mouth: a usually mild contagious viral disease especially of young children that is characterized by fever, malaise, sore throat, and typically painful fluid-filled blisters in the mouth, on the hands and feet, and sometimes in the diaper-covered area and is caused by an enterovirus (species Enterovirus A, especially serotype coxsackievirus A16)
telangiectasia: an abnormal dilation of red, blue, or purple superficial capillaries, arterioles, or venules typically located just below the skin's surface (as on the face)
root: the usually underground part of a seed plant body that functions as an organ of absorption, aeration, and food storage or as a means of anchorage and support and that differs from a stem especially in lacking nodes, buds, and leaves
canal: a tubular anatomical passage or channel : duct
space: a period of time; also : its duration
strabismus: inability of one eye to attain binocular vision with the other because of imbalance of the muscles of the eyeball called also heterotropia, squint
paraparesis: partial paralysis affecting the lower limbs
half-life: the time required for half of something to undergo a process: as
histology: a branch of anatomy that deals with the minute structure of animal and plant tissues as discernible with the microscope
external: capable of being perceived outwardly : bodily
parathyroidectomy: partial or complete excision of the parathyroid glands
mole: a pigmented spot, mark, or small permanent protuberance on the human body; especially : nevus
myeloproliferative: of, relating to, or being a disorder (as leukemia) marked by excessive proliferation of bone marrow elements and especially blood cell precursors
barrier: a material object or set of objects that separates, demarcates, or serves as a barricade
deceleration: to reduce the speed of : slow down
norepinephrine: a catecholamine C8H11NO3 that is the chemical means of transmission across synapses in postganglionic neurons of the sympathetic nervous system and in some parts of the central nervous system, is a vasopressor hormone of the adrenal medulla, and is a precursor of epinephrine in its major biosynthetic pathway —called also arterenol, noradrenaline
pyelitis: inflammation of the lining of the renal pelvis of a kidney
hearing: the act or power of apprehending sound; specifically : one of the special senses of vertebrates that is concerned with the perception of sound, is mediated through the organ of Corti of the ear in mammals, is normally sensitive in humans to sound vibrations between 16 and 27,000 hertz but most receptive to those between 2000 and 5000 hertz, is conducted centrally by the cochlear branch of the auditory nerve, and is coordinated especially in the medial geniculate body
angiodysplasia: an abnormal condition of blood vessels of the gastrointestinal tract and especially the intestine in which vessels are thin, fragile, and enlarged
thalamus: the largest subdivision of the diencephalon that consists chiefly of an ovoid mass of nuclei in each lateral wall of the third ventricle and serves to relay impulses and especially sensory impulses to and from the cerebral cortex
cerclage: any of several procedures for increasing tissue resistance in a functionally incompetent uterine cervix that usually involve reinforcement with an inert substance especially in the form of sutures near the internal opening
anoxia: hypoxia especially of such severity as to result in permanent damage
flare: to break out or intensify rapidly : become suddenly worse or more painful often used with up
pyogenic: producing pus; also : marked by pus production
apical: of, relating to, or situated at an apex
exposed: to subject to risk from a harmful action or condition
atlantoaxial: relating to or being anatomical structures that connect the atlas and the axis
subluxation: partial dislocation (as of one of the bones in a joint)
effector: a bodily tissue, structure, or organ (as a gland or muscle) that becomes active in response to stimulation
idiosyncratic: of, relating to, marked by, or resulting from idiosyncrasy
plastic: made or consisting of a plastic
remodelling: the process of undergoing structural reorganization, alteration, or renewal; especially : the continuous process of bone resorption and formation that involves the activity of osteoclasts and osteoblasts
anisocytosis: variation in size of cells and especially of the red blood cells (as in pernicious anemia)
functions: any of a group of related actions contributing to a larger action; especially : the normal and specific contribution of a bodily part to the economy of a living organism
gadolinium: a magnetic metallic element of the rare-earth group symbol Gd
aquagenic: caused by water and especially by contact with water
palms: the somewhat concave part of the human hand between the bases of the fingers and the wrist or the corresponding part of the forefoot of a lower mammal
gammopathy: a disorder characterized by a disturbance in the body's synthesis of antibodies
cystinuria: a metabolic defect that is characterized by excretion of excessive amounts of cystine in the urine and sometimes by the formation of calculi in the urinary tract and is inherited as an autosomal recessive trait
fibrinolysis: the usually enzymatic breakdown of fibrin
purging: to cause evacuation from (as the bowels) or of or from the bowels of
rapid: a rapid conjugate movement of the eyes associated especially with REM sleep —called also REM
correction: the action or an instance of correcting or neutralizing a harmful or undesirable condition
luteinising: the process of forming corpora lutea
ophthalmoplegia: paralysis of some or all of the muscles of the eye
granulomatosis: a chronic condition marked by the formation of numerous granulomas
polyangiitis: an uncommon disease of unknown cause that is characterized chiefly by inflammation of small blood vessels and granuloma formation especially in the upper and lower respiratory tracts and kidneys and typically has an onset during the ages of 40 to 65
laparotomy: surgical section of the abdominal wall
identification: an act of identifying : the state of being identified
controlled: regulated by law with regard to possession and use
variant: manifesting variety or deviation : varying usually slightly from a usual or standard form
non-polyposis: characterized by the absence of polyps
subglottic: situated or occurring below the glottis
intelligence: the ability to learn or understand or to deal with new or trying situations
tonsil: either of a pair of prominent masses of lymphoid tissue that lie one on each side of the throat between the anterior and posterior pillars of the fauces and are composed of lymph follicles grouped around one or more deep crypts and except for the exposed surface which is covered only by epithelium are surrounded by diffuse lymphoid tissue in a fibrous capsule called also palatine tonsil
adaptation: the act or process of adapting : the state of being adapted
mucoepidermoid: of, relating to, or consisting of both mucous and squamous epithelial cells; especially : being a tumor of the salivary glands made up of mucous and epithelial elements
childhood: the state or period of being a child
anteversion: a condition of being anteverted used especially of the uterus
tibial: of, relating to, or located near a tibia
pseudomembranous: characterized by the presence or formation of a false membrane
observation: the noting of a fact or occurrence (as in nature) often involving the measurement of some magnitude with suitable instruments; also : a record so obtained
heavy: either of the two larger of the four polypeptide chains comprising antibodies
neurotrophic: relating to or dependent on the influence of nerves on the nutrition of tissue
accessory: aiding, contributing, or associated in a secondary way: as
pathway: a line of communication over interconnecting neurons extending from one organ or center to another; also : a network of interconnecting neurons along which a nerve impulse travels
wolff-parkinson-white: an abnormal heart condition characterized by preexcitation of the ventricle and an electrocardiographic tracing with a shortened P-R interval and a widened QRS complex called also WPW syndrome
pica: an abnormal craving for and eating of substances (as chalk, ashes, or bones) not normally eaten that occurs in nutritional deficiency states (as aphosphorosis) in humans or animals or in some forms of mental illness
material: a substance (as a solution of iodine or suspension of barium sulfate) comparatively opaque to X-rays that is introduced into the body (as by injection or swallowing) to contrast an internal part (as the gastrointestinal tract, kidneys, or blood vessels) with its surrounding tissue in radiographic visualization called also contrast agent, contrast material
histiocytic: of, relating to, or containing macrophages
pulp: a mass of soft tissue: as
diaper: a basic garment especially for infants consisting of a folded cloth or other absorbent material drawn up between the legs and fastened about the waist
balanoposthitis: inflammation of the glans penis and of the foreskin
post-acute: a condition that is marked by the presence of symptoms (such as fatigue, cough, shortness of breath, headache, or brain fog) which persist for an extended period of time (such as weeks or months) following a person's initial recovery from COVID-19 infection : long COVID
amniotic: of or relating to the amnion
neurofibromatosis: an inherited developmental disorder characterized especially by brown spots on the skin that are typically present at birth, neurofibromas of peripheral nerves, and deformities of subcutaneous tissues and bone abbreviation NF, NF-1called also Recklinghausen's disease, von Recklinghausen's disease
brachial: of or relating to the arm or a process like an arm
plexopathy: an injured or disordered condition of a plexus and especially a nerve plexus
propionibacterium: a genus (the type of the family Propionibacteriaceae) of gram-positive nonmotile usually anaerobic bacteria that form propionic acid by fermenting lactic acid, carbohydrates, and polyalcohols and that include forms found especially on human skin and in dairy products
morning: an oral drug typically containing high doses of estrogen that is taken up to usually three days after unprotected sexual intercourse or contraceptive failure to prevent or delay ovulation
outer: the outer visible portion of the ear that collects and directs sound waves toward the tympanic membrane by way of a canal which extends inward through the temporal bone
structure: something (as an anatomical part) arranged in a definite pattern of organization
critical: being or relating to an illness or condition involving danger of death
drain: to draw off (liquid) gradually or completely
analytical: of or relating to analysis; especially : separating something into component parts or constituent elements
mycoplasma: the type genus of the family Mycoplasmataceae containing minute pleomorphic gram-negative chiefly nonmotile bacteria that are mostly parasitic usually in mammals
programming: to code in an organism's program
hypermotility: abnormal or excessive movement; specifically : excessive motility of all or part of the gastrointestinal tract
fibrosarcoma: a sarcoma of relatively low malignancy consisting chiefly of spindle-shaped cells that tend to form collagenous fibrils
tracheobronchitis: inflammation of the trachea and bronchi
cystoscopy: the use of a cystoscope to examine the bladder
germ: a small mass of living substance capable of developing into an organism or one of its parts
patella: a thick flat triangular movable bone that forms the anterior point of the knee, protects the front of the joint, increases the leverage of the quadriceps, and is usually regarded as a sesamoid bone since it is developed in the tendon of the quadriceps and in structure is similar to other sesamoid bones called also kneecap, kneepan
polypectomy: the surgical excision of a polyp
diaphragm: a body partition of muscle and connective tissue; specifically : the partition separating the chest and abdominal cavities in mammals
reconstructive: of, relating to, or being reconstructive surgery
toe: one of the terminal members of a vertebrate's foot
papilla: a small projecting body part similar to a nipple in form: as
vater: a trumpet-mouthed dilatation of the duodenal wall at the opening of the fused pancreatic and common bile ducts called also papilla of Vater
pyruvate: a salt or ester of pyruvic acid
margin: the outside limit or edge of something (as a bodily part or a wound)
oncologic: a branch of medicine concerned with the prevention, diagnosis, treatment, and study of cancer
paediatric: of, relating to, or specializing in pediatrics or its practice
interferon: any of a group of heat-stable soluble basic antiviral glycoproteins of low molecular weight that are produced usually by cells exposed to the action of a virus, sometimes to the action of another intracellular parasite (as a bacterium), or experimentally to the action of some chemicals, and that include some used medically as antiviral or antineoplastic agents
gamma: the third letter of the Greek alphabet symbol  or
assay: examination and determination as to characteristics (as weight, measure, or quality)
faecalith: a concretion of dry compact feces formed in the intestine or vermiform appendix
examinations: the act or process of inspecting or testing for evidence of disease or abnormality
relative: the relative capacity of a particular ionizing radiation to produce a response in a biological system abbreviation RBE
tracheostomy: the surgical formation of an opening into the trachea through the neck especially to allow the passage of air; also : the opening itself
resuscitation: an act of resuscitating or the state of being resuscitated
screening: to test or examine for the presence of something (as a disease)
foetoprotein: any of several fetal antigens present in the adult in some abnormal conditions; especially : alpha-fetoprotein
lesions: an abnormal change in structure of an organ or part due to injury or disease; especially : one that is circumscribed and well defined
corpus: the human or animal body especially when dead
orgasm: the climax of sexual excitement that is usually accompanied by ejaculation of semen in the male and by vaginal contractions in the female
mark: a narrow deep hollow on the surface of the crown of a horse's incisor tooth that gradually becomes obliterated by the wearing away of the crown and therefore is indicative of the animal's age and usually disappears from the lower central incisors about the sixth year while traces may remain in the upper until the eleventh
popliteal: of or relating to the back part of the leg behind the knee joint
entrapment: chronic compression of a peripheral nerve (as the median nerve or ulnar nerve) usually between ligamentous and bony surfaces that is characterized especially by pain, numbness, tingling, or weakness
hypobarism: a condition which occurs when the ambient pressure is lower than the pressure of gases within the body and which may be marked by the distension of bodily cavities and the release of gas bubbles within bodily tissues
hypopigmentation: diminished pigmentation in a bodily part or tissue (as the skin)
epidural: situated upon or administered or placed outside the dura mater
ketonuria: the presence of excess ketone bodies in the urine in conditions (as diabetes mellitus and starvation acidosis) involving reduced or disturbed carbohydrate metabolism called also acetonuria
xanthopsia: a visual disturbance in which objects appear yellow
